title.narrative: MDIF Myanmar - financially sustainable media 2019-2022
MDIF Myanmar - finansiellt hållbar media 2019-2022

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Media Development Investment Funds (MDIF:s) "Myanmar Media Program 2" (MMP2) har som övergripande mål att "stärka oberoende nyhetsmedia och förbättra flödet av högkvalitativa nyheter och information för att bidra till Myanmars demokratiska transition." MMP2 kommer att ta sig an utmaningarna för oberoende media att bli långsiktigt finansiellt hållbara och bygga på MDIF:s erfarenheter från det första Myanmarprogrammet 2016-2019 som fokuserade på att bygga kapacitet i affärsverksamhet hos 12 ledande oberoende medieaktörer i Myanmar. MDIF:s första Myanmarprogram hade ett innovativt upplägg för att ta sig an behoven hos oberoende media och kärnan i programmet har varit skräddarsydd kapacitetsutveckling genom coacher från regionen, workshops och utbildningar. Utöver fortsatt kapacitetsutvecklingsstöd för mer sofistikerad media som var inkluderade i det första programmet kommer MMP2 att svara på en ökad efterfrågan av kapacitetsutveckling i affärsverksamhet från små medieaktörer runt om i landet. Det kommer också att ingå aktiviteter som syftar till att stödja en förbättring av professionella standarder inom sektorn som helhet vilket förväntas vara av värde för mediaaktörerna i programmet.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Media Development Investment Fund's (MDIF's) "Myanmar Media Program 2" (MMP2) has the overall objective to "Strengthen the independent news media and improve the flow of high quality news and information to assist Myanmar's democratic transition." MMP2 will tackle the challenges for independent media to become long-term financially viable and build on MDIF's experience of the first MMP 2016-2019 that focused on building business capacity of 12 leading independent media actors in Myanmar. The first MMP has had an innovative approach in addressing the needs of independent media and the core of the program has been tailored capacity development using regional coaches, workshops and trainings. In addition to continued capacity development support to more sophisticated media actors that were included in the first program, the proposed MMP2 will respond to the growing demand for business capacity building from smaller media outlets across the country. This means that MDIF will set up a two-track system of support to answer the needs of the two different scales of media operation. There will also be activities aiming to help improve professional standards within the sector as a whole and that will be of direct benefit to the media partners in the programme.

title.narrative: BBC Media Action: Klahan9, 2019-2020
BBC Media Action: Klahan9, 2019-2020

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 BBC Media Action har inkommit till den svenska ambassaden i Phnom Penh med en begäran om finansiering av en tredje fas av multi-mediainsatsen "Klahan9" i Kambodja under perioden 1 januari 2019 till 30 juni 2020. Insatsen avser att förbättra unga kambodjaners förståelse för arbetsmarknadsfrågor i allmänhet och hur de kan uppnå karriärs- och yrkesrelaterade mål, vilket uppnås genom en kombinerad användning av olika medieplattformar. Den totala budgeten för insatsen uppgår till SEK 14 000 000.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 BBC Media Action has approached the Swedish Embassy in Phnom Penh for funding of SEK 14 million to carry out a third phase of the multi-media intervention "Klahan9" in Cambodia during the period 2019 to 2020. The intervention aims to improve young Cambodians understanding of labour market issues in general and how they can attain their career and employment goals in specific, which is achievedthrough a combined use of different media platforms. The total budget for the intervention amounts to SEK 14 000 000.

The overall objective of Klahan9 is to support young people to take practical steps towards establishing and attaining their career and employment goals which will in turn lead to young people understanding the livelihoods opportunities available to them, navigating the challenges involved in pursuing them and taking action to fulfil their economic potential.

Agreement Amendment II on BBC Media Action's Klahan9 project

Decision on Amendment I of Contribution to BBC Media Action's Klahan9 project
Decision on Amendment II of Contribution to BBC Media Action's Klahan9 project
Decision on Contribution, BBC Media Action: Klahan9 III, 2019-2020
Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: Klahan9 is very much about reaching out to young people through social media. In doing so, the numbers of followers on Facebook are regularly reported. For matter of comparison, the Klahan9 Facebook page had e.g. 302,000 followers in 2016, which rose to over 816,000 in 2019. Indicators such as this do not say much about the impact of an intervention, but can provide some understanding of its popularity and reach. Two evaluations have been undertaken by UNDP during their time as implementing partner of the Klahan9 project, which were reported on in 2016 and 2018 respectively. Below bullet points are the main results from the December 2018 "Final Evaluation of the Project "MIY - Multi-media Initiative for Youth in Cambodia" - Klahan9, that may provide some quick overview of the Project. (The full 2016 and 2018 evaluations may be found in the archive file). Recommendations from both evaluations largely targeted how UNDP could improve its role as manager of the Project. • The overall MIY intervention, including implementation modality have been fully in line with the national strategic priorities for Cambodian and with the needs of the unemployed and youth in vulnerable employment. Preparation and implementation of the MIY project has been characterized with strong technical inputs, national participation and ownership and followed best practices for design and implementation of multi-media approaches; • The final evaluation confirms that implementation of the MIY has been successful and achievement of results has been highly satisfactory. The results could be considered as even more successful when analysed in the context of socio-economic challenges and dynamics within the country, and also complexity and sensitivity of youth employment in Cambodia. • The MIY project introduced multimedia programs as innovative tools and approaches to improve the overall youth employment situation in Cambodia. Also, the project has been effective in involving of youth with disabilities in activities, facilitating their inclusion at the labour market. First report on the current phase of support is expected in January 2020. Results for the first year of implementation will be more coherently reported on then by BBCMA.

title.narrative: Gender mainstreaming advisory (UNW-SEA)
Gender mainstreaming advisory (UNW-SEA)

description.narrative:
The UN Women applied to the Embassy of Sweden for funding of about 16,4 MSEK to carry out the "Gender mainstreaming advisory services to the North Macedonian administration at central level” in the Republic of North Macedonia during 2020-2022 (shorth project title: Gender Equality Facility in North Macedonia) . The intervention aims at increasing long-term capacities and skills of key Government personnel mandated for European Integration and Gender Equality to mainstream Gender Equality goals into the country’s planning and policy processes, so they perform their mandate efficiently and in line with the European Council’s decision of 25th March 2020 to open accession negotiations with the country. The project aim is to stimulate reform processes and policies and to accomplish development of more sustainable institutions, by focusing the institutions that are directly engaged in the preparation and planning of country’s EU accession process.
The intervention is proposed under two complementary strands of engagement:
-In direct partnership with the Secretariat for European Affairs, the project will provide expert support for enhancing the integration of gender perspectives into IPA-supported actions, focusing on sector governance structures such as IPA Units, IPA Coordinators, and Sector Working Groups. -In direct partnership with the Equal Opportunities Department at the Ministry for Labour and Social Policy, the project will strengthen the capacities of line ministries to mainstream gender into documents and processes of the National Programme for the Adoption of the Community acquis, focusing on staff in line ministries and particularly on the essential role of Equal Opportunity Coordinators.
The Project will also attend: - Strenghtening knowledge and capacity building for selected CSO actors will to advocate for and to contribute in gender-responsive policy making processes, as well as to effectively engage in IPA-related governance processes and their monitoring through gender-lens. - Supporting the Government in responding to the significant and gender – specific socio- economic challenges which result from the measures to contain the COVID 19 pandemic.
UN Women will implement the intervention in close cooperation with the Secretariat for European Affairs and the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy of the Republic of North Macedonia.
Sida is the only donor invited by UN Women and the Secretariat for European Affairs for support of this intervention.

UN Women har ansökt till Sveriges ambassad om finansiering på ca 16,4 MSEK för att genomföra projektet " Gender mainstreaming advisory services to the North Macedonian administration at central level" (kortfattad projekttitel: Gender Equality Facility in North Macedonia) i Nordmakedonien under perioden 2020-2022.
Insatsen syftar till att öka långsiktig kapacitet och kompetens hos nyckelpersoner i regeringen som har mandat att arbeta med europeisk integration och jämställdhet. Detta väntas bidra till att dessa nyckelpersoner integrerar jämställdhetsmål i processer för planering och policy samt att de utför sitt mandat effektivt och i linje med Europeiska rådets beslut (25.03.2020) om att inleda anslutningsförhandlingar med landet.
Projektets mål är att stimulera reformprocesser och policys samt att utveckla mer hållbara institutioner med fokus på de institutioner som är direkt engagerade i förberedelserna och planeringen av landets anslutningsprocess till EU.
Insatsen föreslås fokusera på två kompletterande delar:
- Expertstöd för att förbättra integreringen av genusperspektiv i IPA-stödda åtgärder med fokus på sektorstyrningsstrukturer så som IPA-enheter, IPA-samordnare och sektorarbetsgrupper; i direkt samarbete med Sekretariatet för europeiska frågor (Secretariat for European Affairs, SEA).
- Stärka kapaciteten att integrera genusperspektiv i dokument och processer i det nationella programmet för antagande av EUs regelverk vid Ministeriet för arbetsmarknad- och socialpolitik. Detta utförs i direkt samarbete med ministeriets avdelning för jämställdhet. Fokus kommer främst att ligga på personal i ministerier och specifikt den viktiga rollen som samordnare för lika möjligheter.
Vidare kommer projektet även att:
- Öka kunskapen och kapaciteten hos utvalda civilsamhällesaktörer samt stärka deras vilja att förespråka och bidra till genus-responsiva beslutsprocesser, samt att effektivt engagera sig i och följa upp IPA-relaterade styrningsprocesser med genusglasögon.
- Stödja regeringen för att bemöta de betydande och genusspecifika socioekonomiska utmaningarna som följer av åtgärderna för att begränsa spridningen av Covid-19.
UN-Women kommer att genomföra insatsen i nära samarbete med Sekretariatet för europeiska frågor och ministeriet för arbete och socialpolitik i Nordmakedonien.
Sida är den enda givare som har blivit inbjuden av UN-Women och SEA att finansiera denna insats.

The project Gender mainstreaming advisory services to the North Macedonian administration at central level (Gender Equality Facility) contributes to administrative capacity building on central and local level and to enabling the public administration to comply with global norms and standards on gender equality and women empowerment. It is about integrating gender equality perspectives at all stages and levels of policies and strategic programmes prepared by the public administration, by focusing on noticing and addressing the existing gender equality gaps and related lack of knowledge in the responsible institutions. Further, the capacity of the relevant central and local institutions will be strengthened in transposition of the EU gender equality acquis and their performance. The intervention places specific emphases on supporting the Government in responding to the significant and gender-specific socio-economic challenges which result from the measures to cover the COVID-19 pandemic, by implementing the principles of international guidance on gender-responsive recovery, and following the EU’s “Declaration on human rights in times of the coronavirus pandemic” The overall objective of the project is to further strengthen capacity and skills of key Government personnel in North Macedonia mandated for European Integration and Gender Equality, to perform their mandate efficiently for enhanced transposition of the European Union Gender Equality Acquis and in line with the Gender Equality Strategy 2020-2025. The expected single Outcome is - Key Government personnel, mandated for European Integration and Gender Equality, are capacitated to implement the EU Gender Equality Acquis The planned Output 1 is: Secretariat for European Affairs, Sector Working Groups, and IPA units have the knowledge and skills to include gender perspective in programming, implementation, reporting, monitoring and evaluation for IPA programmes The output related activities, among other, include strengthening capacities and enabling preparation of strategic documents like Country's Gender Profile , as well as implementation of basic and advanced trainings on “Gender Mainstreaming in IPA” including provided direct guidance and advice on gender mainstreaming and analysis in priority reform areas and relevant EU chapters (19,22,23,24). The Output 2 attends: National Gender Mechanisms have the administrative capacities to perform gender mainstreaming of National Program for the Adoption of the Acquis planning processes, and to implement Gender Equality legislation and policy in line with EU regulations and international obligations. Support to gender mainstreaming in the drafting and revision of sector strategies, programmes, action plans and funds in priority areas, as well as guidance for introducing EU sector specific gender-mainstreaming, shall be introduced to relevant local counterparts for improved gender responsive and national policy dialogue and for implementing the EU Gender Equality acquis. General public awareness on the support of women’s rights and gender equality shall be achieved through increased transparency of work of the public administration and intensive communication and visibility of project activities. The proposed project responds to Sida’s Strategy Plan for 2020-2022 by focusing on administrative reform and institutional strengthening aiming to contribute to increased confidence in the institutions, and by simultaneously building trust in the administration by the means of strengthened communication of activities and transparency in the functioning of the state apparatus, while reducing the risks of corruption. The project is also about strengthening the Secretariat for European Affairs’ ability to pursue major processes such as EU rapprochement and donor coordination. The project goal directly contributes to the expected results in the Western Balkans as outlined in the Results Strategy for Sweden’s reform cooperation with the Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014-2020. The Strategy areas attended under the project are WB 2014-2020: B1 - Strengthened democracy, greater respect for human rights and a more fully developed state under the rule of law focusing on strengthened public administration and judicial systems (R3 - A more efficient public management with the administrative capacity to implement reforms for EU integration and R4 - Public services delivered with better quality based on principles of non-discrimination and equal rights and with less corruption) and B2 -Strengthened democracy, greater respect for human rights and a more fully developed state under the rule of law focusing on increased enjoyment of human rights and greater opportunities to exercise democratic influence (R11- To bring partner countries closer to meeting international and national commitments to human rights, gender equality including the EU strategy for gender equality, and non-discrimination). Also, the project is responding to the overall priority of promoting gender equality and gender mainstreaming in all cooperation areas. Further, it directly supports the implementation of Agenda 2030, especially contributing to achieve the SDG 5. Furthermore, the project supports women’s influence in all areas of society which is a direct objective of the Swedish Feminist foreign policy, as well as contributes to the priority areas of the Drive for Democracy by promoting equality and social integration, as well as strengthening women’s political participation. The program is initiated and developed in cooperation with the local institutions and it is adjusted to the national context. The current 24 months intervention presents the initial phase of a process that will be followed by a subsequent second phase preferably jointly supported with EU/IPA funding.

title.narrative: Investing in forests and protected areas for climate smart development 1
Investing in forests and protected areas for climate smart development 1

description.narrative:
Projektet syftar till att stärka hållbar förvaltning och skydd av skogs-, natur- och djurskyddsområden samt att skapa förutsättningar för att samhällen som är beroende av dessa naturresurser ska kunna bidra till och dra nytta av ekonomisk utveckling. Takten för avskogning i Uganda är hög, cirka 2,5% per år. Detta får stora konsekvenser för såväl skogsbestånd och biologisk mångfald, som för vilda djur och människors levnadsmiljö och försörjningsmöjligheter.
Den globala Covid-19 pandemin har slagit hårt mot Ugandas turistindustri. Bland annat rapporteras minskade intäkter med omkring 7 miljoner USD per månad för Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA) och den samlade turistindustrin som till stor del är en direkt följd av Covid-19 relaterade reserestriktioner. Uganda Wildlife Authority, men även National Forest Authority (NFA) är i stor utsträckning beroende av sina egna insamlade medel (icke-skatteintäkter) för att driva sin verksamhet. Situationen som utlösts av Covid-19 pandemin, har minskat dessa myndigheters möjligheter att finansiera sin verksamhet, vilket i sin tur lett till brist på skydd av naturresurser samt skydd av vilda djur. Insatsen har som mål att säkra naturresurser samt försörjning för skogberoende samhällen genom kapacitetsutveckling, investeringar i närliggande samhällen samt förbättrad kapacitet hos ansvariga myndigheter, National Forestry Authority (NFA) och Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA).
Projektet kommer att fokusera på utvalda områden inom Albertine-regionen i Uganda. Trots att regionen är rik på naturresurser så som skog, olja och jordbruksmark, och trots utvecklad turistnäring, så är fattigdomen utbredd. Orsaker till att en stor andel av befolkningen (över det nationella genomsnittet) är multidimensionellt fattig, kan bland annat kopplas till bristande resurser, exempelvis tillgång till mark, låg jordbruksproduktivitet, skador på lantbruk orsakade av vilda djur samt miljöförstöring och klimatförändringar. Miljöförstöring och klimatförändringar driver fattigdom i flera dimensioner och minskar människors val och möjligheter att ta sig ur fattigdom. Genom föreslagen insats bedömer Sida att det finns förutsättningar att bidra till fattigdomsminskning på både kort och lång sikt och ur flera av fattigdomens dimensioner. Insatsen bedöms ha en väl balanserad ansats med avseende på bevarande och hållbart utnyttjande av naturresurser å ena sidan och stärkande av två sektorer (skogs- och turistindustri) med särskilt goda förutsättningar för inkluderande ekonomisk utveckling å andra sidan.
Projektets totala budget är 30 miljoner kronor och insatsen är fullt finansierad av Sida. Projektet utgör den första fasen av ett planerat samfinansierat program med både Sida och Världsbanken som finansiärer. Fokus för den första fasen är att säkra naturresurser samt försörjning för de samhällen som är beroende av de aktuella naturskyddsområdena. Fokus är också att stödja förberedande aktiviteter, centrala för projektets andra fas, exempelvis studier samt utformning av infrastruktur som är del av implementering av projektets andra fas. Insatsen sträcker sig över två år (1 oktober 2020 till 30 september 2022) och den kommer att överlappa med starten av fas två. Världsbanken har säkrat finansiering på 148,2 miljoner USD ( 78,2mUSD IDA lån 50mUSD gåvobistånd) för den andra fasen. Under implementering av fas 1 kommer VB att säkra godkännande från den ugandiska regeringen och parlamentet samt påbörja förberedande aktiviteter för den andra fasen. Sidas stöd kommer att påskynda implementeringen och fokusera på omedelbara och eskalerande utmaningar kopplade till den globala pandemin (Covid-19).
Världsbanken är Sidas avtalspartner. Sidas finansiering kommer att bidra till det femte "fönstret" i Världsbankens givargemensamma fond (MDTF) “Partnerskap för stöd till genomförandet av Ugandas nationella utvecklingsplan II och III, en givargemensam fond (TF073022) ”. Den svenska ambassaden i Kampala kommer å Sidas vägnar att underteckna ett administrativt avtal med Världsbanken. VB kommer att vidareförmedla cirka 23 miljoner kronor till de två statliga myndigheterna NFA och UWA för genomförandet av överenskomna aktiviteter. Cirka 4.5 miljoner kronor kommer att användas av VB för finansiering av verksamhet som de själva implementerar. Cirka 2.7 miljoner SEK kommer att utgöra administrationskostnader samt kostnader för uppföljning.
VB har bedömts ha gedigen erfarenhet och god kapacitet att genomföra insatsen både vad avser personalresurser och teknisk expertis. VB har tidigare stöttat Ugandas regering i förberedelserna för REDD + -strategin, vilken syftar till att adressera skogsavverkning och de har tidigare även stöttat turistsektorn. VB bedöms också ha kapacitet att skapa synergier/förmera effekterna från sin breda involvering i ett flertal sektorer i Uganda. De bedöms även kunna bidra till goda utvecklingseffekter genom användandet av en kombination av finansieringsmöjligheter så som gåvor, riskkapital och lån. Ytterligare bedöms de ha förmåga att bidra till positiva attityder och normer i de sektorer där de kommer att vara verksamma.
Världsbanken bedöms ha god styrning och kontroll, exempelvis vad avser finansiell uppföljning, upphandling, konsultationer och koordinering med andra aktörer samt mekanismer som säkerställer social- och miljömässig hållbarhet. Alla dessa faktorer bedöms vara av stor vikt för projektets genomförande.
Insatsen bidrar till flera av Rio-markörerna och givet insatsens fokus på miljö, klimatförändring, klimatanpassning samt biologisk mångfald har "Stöd till miljön" valts som huvudsyfte. Insatsen bidrar även konfliktförebyggande, särskilt med avseende på konflikter kopplade till naturresurser och ökenspridning och därför har freds-/konfliktmarkören valts som delsyfte.
Det strategiska beslutsorganet för den givargemensamma fonden är den så kallade rådgivande kommittén (Joint advisory committee, JAC). Sida kommer att vara representerade i kommittén som observatör. Rapporter från projektet kommer att skickas till kommittén halvårsvis för godkännande. Baserat på rapporterna kommer bilateral uppföljning och dialog att ske mellan Sida och VB. Dessutom kommer Sida att delta i uppföljning genom fältresor som genomförs minst en gång per år som en del av uppföljningen av detta projekt.

The project aims at improving sustainable management of forests and wildlife protected areas in order for communities, who live close to these areas, to be able to benefit from and contribute to inclusive economic development. The project will contribute towards addressing the persistent high rates of forest, habitat and wildlife loss; for example the 2.5% forest loss per year and associated loss of community livelihoods.
Forestry, wildlife and tourism have been hit hard in Uganda by the global Covid-19 pandemic with reported revenue loss of 7 million USD per month for Uganda wildlife Authority (UWA) and the tourism industry, due to Covid-19 related travel restrictions. UWA and the National Forest Authority, (NFA) depend largely on their own collected Non-Tax revenue to run their operations. The Covid-19 situation has reduced capacity of these agencies to finance their operations and exacerbated risks like lack of protection and monitoring of wildlife resources. The project has the objective of securing the natural resource base and preserving livelihoods of forest-dependent communities through capacity development, livelihood investments and improved capacities of mandated agencies, the National Forestry Authority (NFA) and Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA).
The project will focus on selected landscapes within the Albertine Region of Uganda. Despite the region being endowed with natural resources ranging from forests, oil, agricultural land and tourism resources, the area has a high degree of poverty prevalence with multidimensional poverty levels above the national average. Twenty to thirty percent of the population live in food poverty resulting from lack of access to land, low agricultural productivity, crop raiding and environmental degradation. Environmental degradation and climate change drives several dimensions of poverty and creates deprivations in terms of people's opportunities and choice to find a route out of poverty. The proposed intervention is expected to contribute to poverty reduction both in the short and long term and within different dimensions of poverty. The intervention is assessed to have a balanced approach with regards to sustainable use of natural resources on the one hand and strengthening and development of sectors with potential to drive economic growth on the other hand (forestry and tourism).
The project's total budget is 30 million SEK, all of which will be funded by Sida. The project constitutes the first Phase of a planned Sida-World Bank co-funded programme. Funding for this first phase has focus on securing the resource and livelihoods of forest and protected area dependent communities and supporting preparatory activities for the second phase i.e analytical studies and designs of infrastructure to be implemented in the second phase. The first phase constitutes a period of 2 years (1 October 2020 to 30 September 2022) and it will be overlapping with the second phase. The World Bank has secured funding of 148.2 million USD (78.2M IDA loan and 70M Grant) for the second phase. During the first phase, the WB will seek the necessary government and parliamentary approval for phase 2 and start preparations for implementation. In the interim Sida (phase 1) will support activities to address immediate challenges in the face of Covid-19.
The World Bank is Sida’s agreement partner and Swedish funds will be contributing to window number 5 of the WB multi-donor trust fund (MDTF) “Partnership for support to the implementation of Uganda's National Development Plan II and III, a multi-donor trust fund (TF073022)”. The Swedish Embassy in Kampala, on behalf of Sida, will sign an administrative agreement with the World Bank. The WB will sub-grant about 23 million SEK to mandated government agencies NFA and UWA to carry out agreed recipient executed activities. About 4.5 million SEK will fund direct Bank Executed activities. About 2.7 Million SEK will constitute administration and supervision costs.
The WB is assessed to have strong capacity in terms of personnel and technical expertise to implement the project. The WB has been supporting Government of Uganda in preparation of the REDD+ strategy aimed at addressing forest loss and degradation and has previously supported the tourism sector. In addition, the WB has capacity to leverage technical capacity between sectors and leveraging grant, debt and private finance and build positive attitudes and norms in the sector. The WB is also assessed to have strong procedures and controls such as on finance, procurement, stakeholder engagement and environmental and social safeguards, which are considered necessary for implementing such a project in Uganda.
The project contributes to several of the Rio markers as the principle objective notably on Aid to environment, climate change mitigation, climate adaptation and biodiversity. It significantly contributes to conflict prevention, especially related to conflicts over natural resources and desertification.
The Joint Advisory Committee is the strategic decision making body for the MDTF. Sida will participate in the committee as an observer. Reports from the project will be submitted to the committee semi-annually for approval. Based on the reports provided, bilateral follow-up and dialogue will be carried out between Sida and the World Bank. Furthermore, Sida will participate in field missions that will be conducted at least once per year as part of the follow-up of this project.

The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to improve sustainable management of forests and protected areas and increase benefits to communities from forests in selected landscapes within the Albertine Rift Region of Uganda. This project constitutes the first phase of a larger envisioned project with the same objective that will be co-financed by Sida and the World Bank. This project (first phase) aims at securing Uganda's forestry and tourism resources in the Albertine region of Uganda from the prevalent threats of illegal logging, mining, encroachment, poaching and illegal wildlife trafficking that have spiked due to the ongoing global Corona 19 outbreak. The project will further support timely community livelihood programmes in the face of loss of shared revenue from tourism and forestry generated revenues with UWA and NFA, employment in tourism facilities, sale of handcrafts and produce to hotels and restaurants due to effect of the global Covid 19 outbreak. It is imperative to support UWA and NFA in implementation of their core resource protection activities to ensure the protected areas are shielded from encroachment, illegal exploitation, settlement and poaching. Equally it is important to promptly address human wildlife conflicts to minimise damage, attacks and maintain good relationships with communities neighbouring such resources. The protection of forests and wildlife will ensure that post covid 19, forestry and wildlife resources are still available for tourists, ensure satisfaction and generate the much needed tourism revenue and provision of other forest goods and services. The project will further support preparatory actions for the envisioned Sida-World Bank funded Phase 2 by supporting a number of analytical studies and designs for tourism and forestry infrastructure. The World Bank Board has approved a 148.2 million USD for the second phase developed with the Ministries of Water and Environment, Tourism and Antiquities, UWA and NFA with consultation with Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic development (MFPED). In the face of the next coming general elections and now the covid19 situation, the project may take a while to secure the necessary government approvals. Sida funding will in the interim support activities aimed at securing the resource from current pressures and secure community livelihoods as a basis for planned investments in the second phase. The proposed project is based on detailed assessment of drivers of deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) with Government of Uganda and partners in the forestry and tourism and associated sectors that impact this sector such as energy and agriculture. This process resulted in identification of the Albertine as one of the key landscapes for addressing degradation and forest loss in the country.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

15.1 - By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.

15.1 - Till 2020 bevara, återställa och hållbart använda ekosystem på land och i sötvatten och deras ekosystemtjänster, särskilt skogar, våtmarker, berg och torra områden, i enlighet med de skyldigheter som anges i internationella överenskommelser.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.
15.5 - Take urgent and significant action to reduce the degradation of natural habitats, halt the loss of biodiversity and, by 2020, protect and prevent the extinction of threatened species.

15.5 - Vidta omedelbara och betydande åtgärder för att minska förstörelsen av naturliga livsmiljöer, hejda förlusten av biologisk mångfald och senast 2020 skydda och förebygga utrotning av hotade arter.

title.narrative: Etana Citizens Action Network II
Etana Citizens Action Network II

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stödet genom den syriska organisationen Etana syftar till att stärka och föra samman lokala ledare och civila samhällsaktivister i Syrien och återuppbygga förtroendet mellan olika grupper i södra Syrien och Damaskus. Genom dialogen ska också samhällsutvecklingen lokalt stärkas och på sikt bidra till en fredlig och demokratisk utveckling. Etanas mål är också att arbeta med analys av konfliktens utveckling och hålla internationella och syriska beslutsfattare välinformerade för att kunna fatta bättre beslut.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The support through the Syrian organisation Etana aims at supporting local leaders and civil society activists in Syria to connect and to be empowered to maintain some local autonomy in the management of their communities’ affairs and decision-making. The purpose of Etana's activities is also to support local leaders and civil society activists in Syria to rebuild confidence between different sectarian communities in their regions. Etana's goal is also to keep international and Syrian decision-makers well-informed in order to be better decision-makers and pro-actively support the work of Syrian activists.

The overall objective or Etana's "Vision for change" as expressed in the Etana's Strategic Framework is that a peaceful, inclusive future for Syria is possible when citizens, communities, and activists from different backgrounds are connected together and equipped with accurate information to drive positive local-level change that can one day transform into systemic change. Theory of Change If networks of Syrian activists, leaders, civil society, and local communities are well-connected and well-informed, they can effectively work towards building peaceful, inclusive communities. If international and Syrian decision-makers are well-informed, they can be better decision-makers and pro-actively support the work of Syrians activists, leaders, civil society, and local communities. Specific Programming Objectives Local leaders and civil society activists in Syria are connected and empowered to maintain some local autonomy in the management of their communities’ affairs and decision-making. Local leaders and civil society activists in Syria are able rebuild confidence between different sectarian communities in their regions. International and Syrian decision-makers are well-informed in order to be better decision-makers and pro-actively support the work of Syrian activists.

title.narrative: Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: The Peace Network’s areas of focus are currently; accountability on the Russian-guaranteed July 2018 Settlement Agreement; the work with community grievances; working for better service provision as delivery of electricity putting pressure on the owners of the electricity companies, working with consensus building in communities; Advocating and acting for a peaceful approach in the demonstrations in Southwest Syria during second half of 2019. During 2019 281 meetings have been held related to local-decision making and community organizing and 51 activities were conducted between members of different sectarian communities. Etana reports on women’s participation still being low but approaching target of 10 percent participation. The level was six percent for the community organizing meetings and three percent for the meetings with sectarian communities. The Peace Network regularly meets with communities throughout the south-west to understand the status of provision and service needs throughout the region. Overall, the lack of improvement in services after the regime’s takeover was evident, as well as the increasing difficulties communities faced with the plummeting value of the Syrian pound and price inflation of basic commodities. The meetings were often successful in facilitating agreement and consensus between various community stakeholders over how to deal with the regime’s aggressions.Representatives from the Peace Network continued efforts in meeting with the Russians and the regime. This may have lead to the redress of specific issues, although far from resulting in any change of the regime’s or the Russia’s behavior in the South West. The Peace Network also met with INGOs, including the UN and WFP, closer to the latter half of 2019, during their field visits, especially to Busra Al-Sham, to outline the economic conditions and needs in the south-west to an international WFP representative. They also met with Syrian Arab Red Crescent representatives on multiple occasions, as mainly the regime-sanctioned SARC distributed humanitarian aid on occasion following the regime’s takeover. The Peace Network has helped organize the emerging protests in South Syria during fall 2019, both messaging and logistics, reiterating throughout that it was of utmost importance that any local civic actions remain peaceful. Peaceful community actions have proved to be what the regime fears the most, whereas any sort of violent escalation makes it easy for the regime to respond in turn with violence and use its tried and true narrative of “fighting terrorism.” During COVID-19 the peace Network has played a particular role in prevention and planning within communities, while themselves taking the noted public health precautions to take of themselves and prevent transmission as much as possible. Communities are increasingly relying on former opposition local councils to manage the local response to COVID-19 due to the regime's inability/unwillingness to do so. This demonstrates that Peace Network is playing a crucial role in coordinating the reactivation of the local councils and local committees throughout communities and guiding their emergency response strategies. Challenges for the Peace Network The Peace network’s meetings with the INGOs were also often attended by Russian and regime officials, which inevitably created an environment of self-censorship limiting the candidness with which the Peace Network and civilians could candidly speak about the situation and who is responsible for creating it, including deliberate obstacles communities face from the regime when it comes to issues of limiting access or deprivation of services. Moreover, in spite of SARC’s agreement to provide medical, environmental and humanitarian aid – as committed by the regime during the settlement agreement – other than primarily the distribution of food parcels, which dwindled significantly over time, little other assistance was provided to the south-west. As noted already in the low number of women participating in the meeting, a challenge has been considerably diminished space for women to engage in their communities as they had done when the south-west was under opposition control. Instead, concerns about every one's safety, but especially women while moving around the many regime checkpoints, became a major deterrent to their involvement. Gender focus has shifted to the Peace Network focusing on the specific regime policies targeting women or impacting them. The Peace Network has lobbied the regime to stop its policy of calling women who were residents of south-west Syria to Damascus for interrogation, putting them at greater risk for being arbitrarily arrested by any one of the checkpoints along the way, as well as leaving them vulnerable to detention and torture away from the social protection provided by their communities The work with providing international community advocacy reporting has created a now more widely accepted narrative of what regime rehabilitation of a formerly-opposition controlled areas looks like. Etana’s reporting has also drawn particularly attention to the dire situation faced by IDPs in Rukban according to the results framework. There have been overtures of understanding and coming to terms of agreement over IDP communities returning to their homes through mediation and negotiations, some of which the Russians have had an active interest in and thus, helped support. Research has been strengthened during the first phase of the new renewed support and forms the second component. This is a spin-off effect of Etana’s network stemming from all parts of Syria, including the Peace Network. Until December 31, 2019 the research department produced almost 50 reports. The reporting period covering fall 2018 through the end of 2019, was formative as it became clearer that false narratives, misassumptions, and misconstrued information were filling the information voids created by the scale back in cross-border humanitarian and stabilization programming when the regime took over in South Syria 2018 and 2019. Detailed understanding of the contexts, actors, relationships and agendas in the different geographies of controls is a mandatory requirement for designing programming in development and humanitarian aid as well as developing and structuring negotiation and mediation processes, and drawing policies for an array of international donors and diplomatic stakeholders. Etana’s reporting and analyzing trends and dynamics across the different areas of control in Syria, sought to meet this need in order to drive decision-making based on triangulated facts on-the-ground. In order to ensure that Etana’s reporting was engaged with and to help facilitate the information’s digestion by generally time-strained diplomats and decision-makers, Etana regularly conducted closed door briefings to focus on the main messages of research outputs, and engage in discussions and advocacy on what could be done, and what these individual components meant for Syria overall. Advocacy is the third component of Etana's work. Until December 31, 2019 Etana also produced 64 briefings. The briefings and advocacy meetings aims both at facilitating information exchanges between diplomats from different countries who meet together as a group to explicitly counter rumors or false narratives being circulated, as well as to help catch up new diplomats working on Syria on the background and context on the history and actors of an incredibly complex conflict. Perhaps one of the most significant impacts of Etana’s reporting on the situation in Syria, is that it helped counter any assertions that it was safe for refugees to return to Bashar al Assad’s Syria, a narrative that Russia and right-wing political streams in Europe pushed in late 2018, to the detriment of refugee and human rights. Advocacy work has focused mainly the US, EU, UN and UK as key players in negotiations with Russia and Syria. The Special Envoy’s Syria team, both in Geneva and New York, in addition to providing them with remotely conducted briefings have been focus for advocacy work. In addition, Etana’s reporting and staff were cited in numerous prominent news media and think tank publications, including the International Crisis Group, the Middle East Institute, European Institute of Peace, Foreign Policy, Reuters, United States Institute of Peace, Financial Times, Foreign Affairs and Asharq Al-Aswat, on an array of issues, such as the threats to refugee return, the dire conditions in East Ghouta, the regime’s siege on Rukban, the regime’s war profiteers and crony businessmen, and regional complexities around the Druze community in Syria.

title.narrative: COVID-19 PMU (2018-2022) Peace building and trauma
COVID-19 PMU fredsbyggande och trauma, 2018-2022

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Målet med insatsen är att individer, grupper i civilsamhället, kyrkor och institutioner bidrar till förbättrad social samexistens genom att på ett fredligt sätt lyfta bekymmer hos gruppen. Det huvudsakliga syftet med insatsen är: • Främjande av fredlig samexistens, ömsesidigt förtroende, och icke-våldsamma medel för konfliktlösning (detta inkluderar förändrade attityder mot varandra genom att jobba med historiska händelser och trauman, och att få färdigheter för att lösa konflikter fredligt). • Att främja fredliga sätt att uttrycka sitt missnöje på, och kräva sina rättigheter genom att uttrycka sina åsikter på ett konstruktivt vis.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The goal of the intervention is for individuals, CS groups, churches and institutions to contribute to improved social co-existence and to peacefully raising the social concerns of target groups. The main objectives of the intervention are: • Promoting peaceful co-existence and mutual trust, and promoting nonviolent means for Conflict Resolution (this includes changing the attitudes towards the other, dealing with historical grievances and trauma, and gaining the skills to resolve conflicts peacefully) • Promoting peaceful means for the communities to express their grievance and demand their rights through using their Voice constructively

The goal of the intervention is stated as follows: "Individuals, CS groups, churches and institutions contribute to improved social co-existence and to peacefully raising the social concerns of target groups. Two objectives are put forward: Objectives 1: Promoting peaceful co-existence and mutual trust, and promoting nonviolent means for Conflict Resolution (this includes changing the attitudes towards the other, dealing with historical grievances and trauma, and gaining the skills to resolve conflicts peacefully) Objective 2: Promoting peaceful means for the communities to express their grievance and demand their rights through using their Voice constructively.

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.

title.narrative: Agreement
Decision
Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: Results achieved is presented in the annual report for 2020, which is for the new programme officer to follow up on, but following are examples of achievements, which are also presented in the Conclusion of Performance for 2020. Whereas the first year (2019) of the project focussed on Outcome 1, where all planned activities for that period was implemented, the second year (2020) delivered on all three outcomes. One of the main outputs of 2020 is the Training of Trainers (ToTs) sessions that have taken place in all five project zones, reaching more than 150 change agents in local churches and communities. The ToTs have built on the Peace building manual that was produced during the first project year. Another achievement is the Trauma recovery manual, which have been produced and written tailor-made for training of lay councillors in trauma recovery in a Christian setting. This manual will be utilized for ToTs during the third project year. Examples of achievements under each outcome: Outcome 1: Improved capacities of the evangelical churces to respond to peace needs in their communitites and to address ethnocientrism in churches and society. - National level peace conference conducted in March 2020. Particpants included ECFE regional structures, community gatekeepers, denomination leaders and Ministry of Peace. Exampel of direct result from the conference was f ex an initiative by one participant to organise a training on conflict resolution in Bule Hora, Guji. - A TV production on "role of women in Peace buidling" was realised and aired on Walt TV. - Gate keepers' conferences with 150 participants in 5 zones; Bench Sheko in SNNP, West Guji and Shashamane in West Guji in Oromia. To a large extent, the conferences reach out especially to youth. - Training of Trainers (ToT) of local peace builders. A total of 154 trainers took part in the ToTs that was based on the peace manual developed during year 1 of the project. The trainings include that each trainer develop their own action plan to reach out to their respective communitites. To a large extent, the ToTs reach out especially to youth. - Development of a manual for trauma counseling, which will be the foundation for Training of trainers in trauma recovery during the remaining project years. Outcome 2: Women church leaders and women in communities are active in peace building, conflict resolution and trauma healing. PMU reports that it has been a challenge to involve a larger number of women in the project activities because of traditional structures and misconceptions. Work still remains to raise various stakeholders’ awareness and to enhance women's participation, but an encouraging sign of improvement is noted. - The TV production on "role of women in Peace buidling" mentioned above has put the issue on the agenda and triggered discussions on peace and the importance to involve women in peace work. - The most important goal is to include women in the regular work for peace and dialogue and not building parallel structures. However, the a few activities directly addressed women’s participation and gender equality in peace building. One of these interventions is the “Gender equality and the role of women in peace building” seminar that was carried out in each of the project target zones with a total of 151 participants, with the aim to create awareness on gender equality with traditional and religious perspectives. At the end of those seminars 5-7 local female leaders where recruited. Outcome 3: Evangelican churches strengthened to engage with stakeholders to advocate for peace in the communitites. - Three project’s advisory committee (AC) meetings have been conducted during 2020. The AC is essential to both firmly establish the project in the ECFE member churches, and to receive advice from the representatives. - Capacity development of implemnenting partners through trainings in peace building and conflict sensitivity; outcome harvesting for reporting; and project management. Some unexpected results include: - A taskforce established following the Gatekeepers' conference in Bench Sheko zone. The taskforce has assessed the prevailing conflicts in the Bench Sheko zone, mapped the conflict zones, and developed an action plan with the budget. The Bench Sheko Zone Administration has accepted the Strategic/action plan with slight modification and promised to fund some of the activities. - A taskforce established following the conference in Shambu, Horo Guduru, with the main aim to periodically gather to discuss peace and security issues in their area and working with government agents to develop solutions. - ECFE was given the opportunity to, in collaboration with Ahadu Radio and Television, organize a panel discussion on the topic of Youth and Peace, which was broadcasted live on radio, with a condensed version aired on Ahadu Television. Challenges and major events during 2020 * The COVID-19 pandemic presented its first case in Ethiopia in March 2020, and in early April the Federal government declared a state of emergency. As for most partners in the country, the effects of the pandemic and the restrictions on such things as travel and meetings, posed major challenges on the programme.PMU, in consultation with the programme officer at the embassy, showed flexibility in adapting activities to ensure continued implementation; meetings and trainings were f ex conducted in larger halls and with relevant C19 prevention. In addition, PMU added COVID-19 mitigation measures like distributing hand-washing kits and information material in the areas of implementaiton, which was positively received and proved to help in creating trust by the communities. * Increasing violence and tensions in most part of Ethiopia has affected the project, mainly by the violence in Oromia region since three of the project implementation areas are found there. The most serious of these events took place in June 29 when a famous Oromo singer activist was assassinated. Following the death of the artist, youth in almost all parts of the Oromia region began to protest, and several hundred people were killed. Another project area where large scale violence has broken out is Guraferda in Bench Sheko zone in SNNP region.Some activities have been slightly postponed due to sudden violent outbreaks in project areas. The vast church network of our implementing partner ECFE has proven to be an asset when navigating in violent areas and for gathering necessary information to take relevant security precautions. * Altough the project is not implemented in Tigray, PMU notes that also the war in Tigray that started early November 2020 pose a risk and potential challenge to the project, due to the growing uncertainty in the country.

title.narrative: COVID-19 UN Women: Kvinnors egenmakt i Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
COVID-19 UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021

description.narrative: By the end of the intervention, it is expected that: Women and girls, both Rohingya and host community, are empowered and resilient leaders, and are able to address and build social cohesion. The specific outcomes of this project will be: 1. Women have increased capacity and skills to participate and lead in community management and decision-making, in an enabling environment, and are linked with host community women, promoting social cohesion. 2. Capacities, skills and livelihood opportunities of women and adolescent girls are developed to enhance their self-reliance. 3. Capacity of all Camp-in-Charge (CiCs) is enhanced to enable gender-sensitive response to concerns (including protection needs) of women/girls and to able to provide better humanitarian services to all.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UN Women har ansökt om finansiering om 6,231 miljoner USD, ca 60 miljoner SEK för att utföra insatsen "Means to Lead: Empowering Rohingya refugee and Host Community Women through Leadership, Learning and Livelihoods" i Rohingya lägren i Bangladesh under perioden september 2019 - augusti 2022.
Insatsen syftar till att tillse att kvinnor och tonårsflickor i flyktinglägren i Cox´s Bazar har möjlighet att stärka sin egenmakt, sitt ledarskap och motståndskraft genom ökad kunskap och färdigheter. Detta ska göras genom att tillse 1) att kvinnor deltar i och leder beslutsfattande fora i lägren och att Rohingya kvinnor stärker länkarna med kvinnor i värdsamhället för att öka den sociala sammanhållningen; 2) att unga kvinnor och ungdomar får tillgång till utbildning, får möjlighet att utveckla färdigheter och får tillgång till egen inkomst; och 3) att Camp-In-Charges (CiC) stärker sin kapacitet för att bemöta kvinnors behov, för att utveckla skyddsåtgärder, och för att förbättra kvinnors tillgång till humanitära tjänster utan diskriminering. Den totala budgeten för verksamheten, egentligen en total budget för tre sammanslagna projekt, beräknas uppgå till 76 000 000 kronor, varav 38 450 000 kronor kommer att vidareförmedlas till implementeringspartners. Sida finansierar 79 % av den totala projektbudgeten.
Under år två och tre kommer insatsen skifta sitt fokus till det bredare Cox's Bazar-distriktet, i linje med pågående diskussioner kring en kommande lokal utvecklingsplan för distriktet, samt i ökad grad rikta in sig på värdsamhällen för att tydligare täcka behoven i ett av Bangladesh fattigare distrikt och samtidigt stärka förutsättningarna för distriktet att fortsatt vara värd för den stora flyktingbefolkningen.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 UN Women has applied for funding of SEK 60 00 000 to carry out the intervention "Means to Lead: Empowering Rohingya refugee and Host Community Women through Leadership, Learning and Livelihoods" in the Rohingya refugee camps and surrounding host comunities in Cox´s Bazar during the period September 2019 – August 2022.
The project aims to empower women, young women and adolescent girls in refugee camps and make them more resilient leaders by ensuring 1) women have increased capacity and skills to participate and lead in community management and decision-making, in an enabling environment, and are linked with host community women, promoting social cohesion; 2) capacities, skills and livelihood opportunities of women and adolescent girls are developed to enhance their self-reliance, and 3) capacity of all Camp-in-Charge (CiCs) are enhanced to enable gender-sensitive response to concerns (including protection needs) of women/girls and they are able to provide better humanitarian services to all. UN Women will implement the intervention through international non-governmental organizations with presence in the Rohingya refugee camps.
The intervention´s total budget is estimated to SEK 76 000 000, a total budget of three combined projects, and Sweden finances 79 % of the intervention. Approximately SEK 38 450 000 of the intervention budget will be forwarded from UN Women to implementing partners.
The intervention is relevant for the implementation of results area 5 in the Results strategy for Bangladesh 2014-2020, which aims to strengthen the capacity to prevent crises, conflicts and disasters, and increased resilience. Focus in this sub-result area is on vulnerable groups in refugee reception areas, among host communities and Rohingya refugees, especially women and children. The contribution also contributes towards sustainable development goals (SDGs) on gender equality (SDG 5) and on peace, justice and strong institutions (SDG 16).
During year 2 and 3, the intervention will shift its focus to target the wider Cox's Bazar district, in line with current discussions on a forthcoming district development plan, and increasingly target host communities to increasingly cover needs in one of Bangladesh's poorer districts, while increasing the districts ability to continue hosting the large refugee population.

participating-org.narrative: UNWOMEN/United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women
United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women

sector.narrative: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

title.narrative: UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: During the first part of the project, UNWomen focused on establishing the relationship with authorities, consulting key target groups, identifying implementing partners etc. Despite the lockdown during parts of the year, several key activities were implemented in line with the revised work plan. For instance, the following activities were achieved: - A joint rapid gender analysis on COVID-19 in Cox’s Bazar was, based on secondary data, conducted. To follow-up further on the secondary data gender analysis findings, primary data collection was conducted in camps and host communities for the drafting of a more elaborate Rapid Gender Analysis of the impact of COVID-19 in Rohingya and host communities. - As a part of reprogramming of women’s leadership activities due to COVID-19, OXFAM's female community-based volunteers conducted door-to-door community engagement and awareness-raising sessions on COVID-19. - Through the five UN Women Multi-Purpose Women Centres (MPWC) in the camps, 7,681 Rohingya women and girls accessed life-saving information and services. This included support to survivors of SGBV. - Through the deployment of six UN Women Gender Field Officers seconded to Camps-in-Charge covering 13 camps supported by 40 Rohingya volunteers, UN Women strengthened regular monitoring at the camp level and provided technical support to strengthen the integration of gender considerations by Camps-in-Charge (CiCs).

title.narrative: UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: During the first part of the project, UNWomen focused on establishing the relationship with authorities, consulting key target groups, identifying implementing partners etc. Despite the lockdown during parts of the year, several key activities were implemented in line with the revised work plan. For instance, the following activities were achieved: - A joint rapid gender analysis on COVID-19 in Cox’s Bazar was, based on secondary data, conducted. To follow-up further on the secondary data gender analysis findings, primary data collection was conducted in camps and host communities for the drafting of a more elaborate Rapid Gender Analysis of the impact of COVID-19 in Rohingya and host communities. - As a part of reprogramming of women’s leadership activities due to COVID-19, OXFAM's female community-based volunteers conducted door-to-door community engagement and awareness-raising sessions on COVID-19. - Through the five UN Women Multi-Purpose Women Centres (MPWC) in the camps, 7,681 Rohingya women and girls accessed life-saving information and services. This included support to survivors of SGBV. - Through the deployment of six UN Women Gender Field Officers seconded to Camps-in-Charge covering 13 camps supported by 40 Rohingya volunteers, UN Women strengthened regular monitoring at the camp level and provided technical support to strengthen the integration of gender considerations by Camps-in-Charge (CiCs).

title.narrative: Capacity Building Social Protection 2019-2022
Kapacitetsbyggande sociala trygghetssystem 2019-2022

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen gäller stöd om 60 000 000 SEK till den andra fasen av Joint UN Programme on Social Protection under åren 2019 - 2022. Avtalspart är UNICEF och medverkande FN-organisationer är WFP och ILO. Den första fasen genomfördes mellan 2016 och 2019 och fick stöd av Finland, Irland, UK samt Sverige. Fortsättningen bygger vidare på resultat och erfarenheter från den första fasen och har ett något snävare fokus på i första hand att bygga system och kapacitet kring socialbidragssystemet för de allra fattigaste i Zambia. Ytterligare viktiga komponenter är integrering av jämställdhet, anpassning för funktionshindrade, förbättrad nutrition för gravida och ammande kvinnor samt system för ökade utvecklingseffekter genom förbättrade länkar mellan socialbidrag och andra insatser sk Cash+. En ytterligare komponent gäller utbetalning av extra socialbidrag under 2019 och 2020 till mottagare i distrikt som är särskilt drabbade av torka. Programmets ska finansieras gemensamt av Sverige och UK.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to the second phase of the Joint UN Programme on Social Protection 2019-2022. Agreement partner is UNICEF and the participating UN Organisations are WFP and ILO. The first phase was implemented between 2016 and 2019 and was supported by Finland, Ireland, UK and Sweden. The continuation builds upon the results and lessons learned in the first phase but is more focused on building systems and capacity around the social cash transfers for the poorest in Zambia. Other important Components of the programme are mainstreaming of gender and disability, improved nutrition for pregnant and lactating mothers as well as increased development effects through enhanced operational links between social cash transfers and other initiatives, so called cash+. An additional component deals with Emergecy Cash Transfers during 2019 and 2022 to households in districts that are hardest hit by the prolonged reduced rainfalls. The programme is to be funded by Sweden and UK.

The Joint UN Programme on Social Protection phase II has the following expected results: Impact: Reduced Multi-dimentional poverty Outcomes: 1. Predictable and regular Social Cash Transfers 2. Operational Cash+ linkages 3. Improved nutrition 4. Disability mainstreaming 5. Improved cluster perfomace In addition the programme has a component of Emergency Cash Transfers with payments during 2019 and 2020 to social cash beneficiaries in the districts hardest hit by the prolonged reduced rainfall.

sector.narrative: Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

tag.narrative: 1.3 - Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.
1.3 - Införa nationellt lämpliga system och åtgärder för socialt skydd för alla, inklusive grundskydd, och senast 2030 säkerställa att de omfattar en väsentlig andel av de fattiga och de utsatta.

1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.

2.2 - By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.

2.2 - Senast 2030 avskaffa alla former av undernäring, bland annat genom att senast 2025 nå de internationellt överenskomna målen i fråga om tillväxthämning och undervikt bland barn under fem år, samt tillgodose tonårsflickors, gravida och ammande kvinnors samt äldre personers näringsbehov.

title.narrative: UNJHRO - institutionellt stöd till skydd av mänskliga rättigheter
UNJHRO - programme support to protect human rights

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stödet till JHRO har två komponenter: "Civic Space Project" och "Senior Women Protection Adviser". Genom projekten finansieras upp till 70% av MR-kontorets verksamhet i DRK och Sidas stöd utgör därför i princip ett kärnstöd till landverksamheten.
Komponenten the Civic Space Project syftar till att skydda och utöka det demokratiska utrymmet och skapa nödvändiga förutsättningar för DRK att förstärka sin demokrati genom full respekt för mänskliga rättigheter som bas för fred och stabilitet i landet. Att utöka det demokratiska utrymmet möjliggör för rättvisa och transparanta val på olika nivåer vilket utökar befolkningens aktiva deltagande. Projektet ska skydda och främja mänskliga rättigheter genom att öka både kapaciteten och ägandeskapet för nationella institutioner och civilsamhällsorganisationer att övervaka och rapportera efterlevnaden av mänskliga rättigheter. Projektet syftar även till att öka ansvarsutkrävande för brott, bekämpa straffriheten och skydda vittnen, offer och aktivister så att de effektivt kan utöva sin roll.
Förutom att aktivt arbeta för att övervaka och rapportera om efterlevnaden av mänskliga rättigheter kommer JHRO utbilda och träna nationella institutioner, civilsamhällsorganisationer, aktivister och journalister. JHRO kommer att stötta nationella institutioner som National Human Rights Commission, parlamentets MR-kommission och departementet för mänskliga rättigheter i deras arbete genom riktad utbildning samt logistiskt stöd. Aktivister, offer och vittnen kommer att skyddas genom aktiviteter såsom identifiering av "early-warning," skapande av nätverk och tillhandahållande av psykosocialt stöd. Genom logistik- och tekniskt stöd till juridiska institutioner samt assistans och juridisk hjälp till offer och vittnen, främst kvinnor, kommer straffrihet bekämpas.
Projektet implementeras över hela landet med ett mobilt team som täcker de områden där JHRO eller OHCHR inte har egen närvaro. Främst och till att börja med på orter där JHRO inte längre har egen närvaro ska lokala aktörer gradvis ta över ansvaret för att skydda och främja efterlevnaden av de mänskliga rättigheterna och folkets deltagande i demokratiska val.
Komponenten SWPA Project ligger under mandatet för FN:s generalsekreterares särskilde sändebud för sexuellt våld i konflikt och syftar till att stärka FNs möjlighet att fördjupa kampen mot konfliktrelaterat sexuellt våld i DRK. Projektet fokuserar på stöd till rådgivarens övervakning och analys av konfliktrelaterat sexuellt våld genom att möjliggöra en nära kontakt med konfliktparterna och stärka rådgivarens arbete att utöva påtryckning för skydd av kvinnor och flickor, pojkar och män. SWPA är baserad i Kinshasa och har till sin hjälp fyra fältbaserade rådgivare. SWPA koordinerar arbetet av de fältbaserade rådgivarna samt MONUSCOs MARA (Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Arrangements) i deras roller att övervaka, analysera och rapportera om situationen angående sexuellt våld samt identifiera och hjälpa offer och vittnen. Rådgivaren ska utöva påtryckning för att polisens och arméns implementerar sina planer för att minska sexuellt våld bland de egna leden, ska stärka icke-statliga aktörers engagemang samt se till att arbetet för att minska konfliktrelaterat våld är integrerat på strategisk och operationell nivå hos alla relevanta aktörer i FN-missionen (polis, militär, civil).

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The support to JHRO has two components: a Civic Space Project and a Senior Women's Protection Adviser. These projects will fund up to 70% of the JHRO country operations and will, thus, in principal constitute core support to the office.
The aim of the component the Civic Space Project is to contribute to protect and widen the democratic space and create the necessary conditions for DRC to consolidate the democracy through the full respect and effective exercise of all human rights as a base for stability and peace in the country. Widening the democratic space will enable fair and transparent elections at different levels which will increase the active participation of the people. The project will protect and promote human rights through increasing both the capacity and the ownership of national institutions and civil society organisations to monitor and report on the human rights situation. The project also aims to increase the accountability for perpetrators of HRV, fight impunity and protect witnesses, victims and activists so that they can effectively perform their role.
Apart from actively working to monitor and report human rights, the JHRO will also educate and train national institutions, civil society organisations, activists and journalists. JHRO will support national institutions such as the National Human Rights Commission, the Parliamentary Human Rights Commission and the department for human rights in their work through targeted education and logistical support. Activists, victims and witnesses will be protected through activities such as identification of early warning, creation of networks and providing psychosocial support. Impunity will be fought through logistical and technical support to judicial authorities as well as legal assistance to victims and witnesses, in principal to women.
The project will be implemented country wide with a mobile team covering the areas where JHRO or OHCHR are not present. Starting in locations where the JHRO is no longer present, the responsibility to protect and promote human rights and people's participation in democratic elections will gradually be handed over to local CSOs.
The SWPA component lies under the mandate of the UNSRSG on sexual violence in conflict and the aim of this component is to strengthen the UN's possibility to consolidate the fight against conflict-related sexual violence in DRC. The project will focus on supporting the Senior Women Protection Adviser ‘s deployment to reinforce the monitoring and analysis of conflict related sexual violence, further engage with parties to the conflict to more effectively prevent CRSV and advocate for the protection of women, girls, boys and men. The SWPA is based in Kinshasa and is coordinating four field-based Women Protection Advisors. The SWPA coordinates the work of the field-based advisors and the MONUSCO MARA (Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Arrangements) in their respective role to monitor, analyse and report the situation of conflict related sexual violence and to identify and support victims and witnesses. the SWPA shall perform advocacy for the full implementation of the national action plans of the police and military to decrease sexual violence internally, shall support the engagement of non-state actors, and shall ensure that CRSV considerations will continue to be mainstreamed throughout the responsibilities of relevant mission components (military, police and civilian) at strategic and operational level.

participating-org.narrative: OHCHR/Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights
United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (extrabudgetary contributions only)

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
