title.narrative: Stöd UN Womens interim landprogram DRK
Support to UN Women interim strategic note DRC

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Ambassaden kommer att stödja UN Womens landkontor under den sista fasen av sin strategiska plan 2014-2017, som har förlängts till 2019, samt lanseringen av sin nya strategiska plan från 2020. Stödet är en övergångsfinansiering på 9 månader. Intentionen är att ambassaden ska ge långsiktigt stöd för den nya strategiska planen från 2020, och möjligheten att göra så kommer att bedömmas under slutet av 2019.
Målet med den strategiska planen för 2014-2017 som förlängdes fram till 2019, är att stödja den kongolesiska regeringen och det civila samhället och andra berörda aktörer att genomföra, övervaka och rapportera om DRKs åtaganden om jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt. UN Womens grundläggande roll i DRK är att tillhandahålla stöd till nyckelpartner och aktörer, ge tekniskt stöd och expertis, främja effektiv samordning / uppföljning / utvärdering, dokumentera resultat, samt att generera och främja användningen av sex-disaggregerad data. De fokusområden som beskrivs i den strategiska noten är följande: samordning; stärkt jämställdhetsperspektiv av planering och budgetering; våld mot kvinnor och flickor; kvinnor, fred och säkerhet; kvinnors politiska ledarskap och deltagande; samt kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt. Av dessa har tre områden prioriterats mer specifikt av UN Women när förlängningen av den strategiska planen godkändes 2017: kvinnor, fred och säkerhet; inklusive könsbaserat våld; kvinnors politiska ledarskap och deltagande; och kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt. Dessa alla motsvarar ambassadens och Sida prioriteringar.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The embassy will support the UN Women DRC office in the final period of implementation of their strategic note 2014-2017, extended until 2019, and the launch of their new strategic note from 2020. The support is a bridge funding to cover 9 months. The intention is for the embassy to continue to support the new strategic note from 2020, and the feasibility of doing so will be assessed during the latter part of 2019.
The goal of the strategic note for the 2014 - 2017, extended until 2019, is to support the Congolese government and civil society, and other concerned actors to implement, monitor and report on DRC's commitments to gender equality and women's empowerment. The fundamental role of UN Women in DRC is to accompany key partners and actors, provide technical support and expertise, promote effective coordination/monitoring/evaluation, document results, generate and promote the use of sex disaggregated data. The focus areas as outlined in the strategic note are as follows: coordination; gender responsive planning and budgeting; violence against women and girls; women, peace and security; women's political leadership and participation; women's economic empowerment. Three areas were prioritized further by UN Women when the extension of the strategic note was agreed in 2017: Women, peace and security, including SGBV; women's political leadership and participation; and women's economic empowerment. These all correspond to priorities of the embassy and Sida.

The embassy will support the UN Women DRC office in the final phase of implementation of their strategic note and the launch of their new strategic note from 2020. The goal of the strategic note for the 2014 - 2017, extended until 2019, is to support the Congolese government and civil society, and other concerned actors to implement, monitor and report on DRC's commitments to gender equality and women's empowerment. The fundamental role of UN Women in DRC is to accompany key partners and actors, provide technical support and expertise, promote effective coordination/monitoring/evaluation, document results, generate and promote the use of sex disaggregated data. The focus areas as outlined in the strategic note are as follows: coordination; gender responsive planning and budgeting; violence against women and girls; women, peace and security; women's political leadership and participation; women's economic empowerment. Three areas are prioritized further by UN Women: Women, peace and security, including SGBV; women's political leadership and participation; and women's economic empowerment. These all correspond to priorities of the embassy and Sida.

title.narrative: Think Nature med CPCD
Think Nature with CPCD

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektet ”Think Nature!” kommer att genomföras i Bosnien och Hercegovina under en tre-års period. Målet är att öka inflytandet från det civila samhället på miljöskyddet, bidra till bättre miljöskydd och stärka motståndskraft mot miljöpåverkan och klimatförändringar i Bosnien och Hercegovina samt också stärka genomförandet av de krav som ställs av EU och internationella avtal för miljö, klimat och energi.
Insatsen ska omfatta olika aktiviteter som kommer leda till ökat miljöansvar hos myndigheter, företag och medborgare genom kampanjer; öka engagemanget från de lokala aktörer i att hantera miljöfrågor och genom att etablera nätverk med 10 Eco Hubs; uppmuntra ungdomar att vara engagerade i miljöfrågor och skydda miljön genom utvecklingen av 40 miljöskolor; öka medvetenheten och aktivismen hos ungdomar inom miljöskyddsområdet; och förbättra kvantiteten och kvaliteten i media om miljö.
Projektet ska involvera olika intressenter; miljöorganisationer, media, medborgare (särskilt ungdomar), företag, grund- och gymnasieskolor, lokala och nationella myndigheter. Projektet är utformat för att uppmärksamma tvärgående frågor, som tex aspekter av multidimensionell fattigdom, konfliktförebyggande, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och miljö. Alla projektkomponenter kommer ha en stark komponent om jämställdhet och en handlingsplan kommer att utvecklas inom startfasen.
” Civil Society Promotion Center (CPCD)” ska ansvara för projektledning och genomförandet. CPCD är en bosnisk icke-statlig organisation som verkar över hela landet. CPCD uppfyller alla krav för att skriva avtal med. CPCD har existerat i 22 år och har byggt upp en distinkt position som en professionell organisation. CPCD är ledande i samarbete med medborgare, kompetensuppbyggnad av civilsamhällsorganisationer (CSOs), uppbyggnad av demokrati och det civila samhället i BiH, samt vet hur man skapar nya möjligheter för medborgare. CPCD har ett starkt nätverk av associerade företag över hela Bosnien och Hercegovina som omfattar CSO: er, representanter för den statliga sektorn, experter, företag och individer. CPCD ägnar särskild uppmärksamhet åt utvecklingen av strategiskt samarbete med media och stark närvaro i sociala medier. CPCD har 12 heltidsanställda och tre praktikanter. Den årliga omsättningen för det senaste räkenskapsåret var 3,5 miljoner BAM. CPCD: s expertkunskap är inte uteslutande kopplat till miljöfrågor, även om de har viss erfarenhet inom miljöområde. CPCD planerar att rekrytera en projektrådgivaren med expertis inom miljö.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The “Think Nature!” is three-year project that will be implemented on whole territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Main objective of the project is to increase influence of civil society on environment protection, and by that, to contribute to better environment protection and enhanced resilience to environmental impact and climate change in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to strengthen implementation of the requirements imposed by the EU and international agreements on the environment, climate and energy. The intervention involve a set of different activities, which will lead to increasing environmental responsibility of government bodies, companies and citizens through advocacy campaigns; increasing involvement of local actors in addressing environmental issues through establishing infrastructure/network of 10 Eco Hubs; encouraging young people to engage in their environment and actively protect it through development of 40 Eco Schools; raising awareness and activism of young people in area of environment protection; and improving the quantity and quality of environmental coverage in media. This project will involve variety of key stakeholders, such as environmental CSOs, media, citizens (especially young people), companies, primary and secondary schools, local and national government. Project is designed to pay attention to cross cutting issues, such as aspects of multidimensional poverty, conflict prevention, human rights, gender equality and environment. All project components include strong gender component which action plan will be developed within inception phase..
The Civil Society Promotion Center (CPCD) will assume responsibility for project management and implementations. CPCD is a Bosnian non-governmental organization that operates across Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region of the Western Balkans and it fulfils all requirements to enter into an agreement. Over 22 years, the CPCD has built a distinctive position as a professional organization, leader in working with citizens, competency-building of civil society organizations (CSOs), as well as the building of democracy and civil society in BiH and creating new opportunities for its citizens. The CPCD has a strong network of associates all over BiH and the Western Balkans region that encompasses CSOs, representatives of the governmental sector, experts, companies, and individuals. The CPCD pays special attention to the development of strategic cooperation with the media, and to strong presence in social media. Currently, CPCD has 12 full-time employees, and three interns. Annual turnover for last Fiscal Year was 3,5 million BAM. The expertise of CPCD is not exclusively linked to environmental matter, though they have certain experience in this field amongst the others. For this specific project CPCD will recruit the project advisor with expertise in environment.

The main objective of the intervention is to increase influence of civil society on environment protection, and by that, to contribute to better environment protection and enhanced resilience to environmental impact and climate change in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to strengthen implementation of the requirements imposed by the EU and international agreements on the environment, climate and energy. Think Nature! is three-year project that will be implemented on whole territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The intervention will be implemented through set of different activities, which will aim to achieve following results: To increase environmental responsibility of government bodies, companies and citizens through advocacy campaigns.To increase involvement of local actors in addressing environmental issues through establishing infrastructure/network of 10 Eco Hubs To encourage young people to engage in their environment and actively protect it through development of 40 Eco Schools. To raise awareness and activism of young people in area of environment protection.To improve the quantity and quality of environmental coverage in B&H media. A well-structured plan with clearly measurable objectives and well-defined, relevant activities and indicators, is presented in logframe attached to the proposal. Logframe will be used as a tool for monitoring and follow up of the project during implementation.

title.narrative: Agreement
Decision on agreement
Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: Highlights of the main achievements within reporting period are: Advocacy In the first year of the project, an environmental organizations database was created, which is updated daily. So far 327 organizations have been identified (plan was to identify and have 200 entries) familiar with the project objectives. Following the public calls competitive procedure, 5 Network advocacy grants, 6 Media advocacy grants and 3 Corporate Responsibility grants have been awarded. The Handbook for Advocacy Campaigns towards the Companies has been created. It combines international theory and standards, practice and local experience. The manual is available to the citizens of BiH on the project website. Eco HUBs Following the public call, 9 organizations have been selected as Eco HUBs, that are from June 1, 2020 project’s strategic partners. Established Eco HUBs are in Sarajevo (Aarhus centar), Banja Luka (Lir evolution), Mrkonjic Grad (Green ways), Laktaši (CERD), Maglaj (Fojnicani), Zenica (Eko forum), Blagaj (Novi Val), Mostar (Nešto Više) i Široki Brijeg (Eko ZH). In cooperation with WWF Adria, the plan is to include the Tourist Cluster Una Sana Bihac in the network of Eco HUBs. Duration of the project implementation for selected Eco HUBs is 26 months (with exception for three Eco HUBs who signed contract agreement earlier in May which is 27 months). Selected Eco HUBs need to establish themselves as resource center for environmental issues in their geographical area. In addition, three Eco HUBs together with the CPCD are implementing the campaign “I plant, and you?” The campaign is largely communicated through the project’s already established website and social media network. Methodology for emergency micro gardening intervention was created as a document that represents a basic strategy approach for the “Think Nature!” project in sharing knowledge and approach to other Eco HUBs. Mentorship for Eco HUBs is provided by Eco HUB Mostar and it included online working with the staff of two HUBs and strengthening their capacities. The Manual for microstructure/preparedness phase is a practical guideline with explanations, tips, drawings and photographs that can help an interested person, with no previous knowledge, on how to transfer their balcony or gardens into a successful small garden with edible, medicinal, spice/seasoning plants and useful gardening flowers. Eco Schools A working group was formed that worked for months on the development of the Certification Mechanism for schools, which is the base for the implementation of the program based on international practices and educational conditions in BiH. In the first year of the project, a comprehensive Eco School certification tool, a school manual and a school curriculum with five teaching units for primary and five for secondary schools were developed in order to improve the created supportive environment and educational content in extracurricular processes. At this stage of the project, communication was made with the relevant ministries of education to issue permits to work with schools, and all ministries issued permits except the RS ministry. As response to COVID-19, additional activities have been integrated into the project, and their implementation was in the period May - August. COVID-19 related activities are the creation of a methodology for the development of school preparation plans for health crises in accordance with the Save the Children methodology related to response plans in other crises, then the development of manuals for online teaching, and selection of suppliers to support school by providing them with the disinfection. Youth A detailed campaign plan for young people was created, which had been modified in early 2020 due to the pandemic, and later in September, it was modified again in accordance with the new findings regarding the pandemic. Outdoor promotion/campaign was set from August 5 until September 2, 2020. Campaign was envisioned as opportunity for youth to shoot videos with environmental messages. Unfortunately, in given moment it was not possible to proceed with the initial idea, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Given the fact that media is overwhelmed with the information and reporting about COVID-19 pandemic, project team shift campaign focus to the Think Nature! website, asking general public what they can do for nature and invited them to find more information at web site www.mislioprirodi.ba and Think Nature! social media Facebook, Instagram, Tik Tok and Twitter. Media promotion campaign was very intensive during the reporting period. Eco journalist Twenty journalists from all over Bosnia and Herzegovina participated in the Training for journalists on environmental topics. Cooperation with the journalists continued, trough reporting on activities within the "Think Nature!" project, and in terms of writing about environmental issues in general. Journalists who participated in the training were included in the journalists' database created in the first weeks of the project and were regularly informed about the project activities. Among them were journalists experienced in this field, and those who after the training started to make the first journalistic steps in the field of environmental protection. In February, project reached out public universities in Sarajevo, Tuzla, Mostar, Banja Luka, Eastern Sarajevo, and private universities in Travnik and Banja Luka, explaining the primary goals of the "Think Nature!" project, as well as the goals of cooperation with the faculties. Promotion Promotion of the project is a cross-cutting component and it’s going to be systematically tackled during the whole duration of the project in coordination with all project stakeholders and components of the project.

title.narrative: GED 3 Energieffektivitet i offentliga byggnader
GED 3 Energy Efficiency in Public Sector Buildings

description.narrative:
Green Economic Development fas III har som målsättning att ytterligare främja ökad energieffektivitet i Bosnien och Hercegovina (BiH) och skapa gynnsamma miljöer för investeringar för åtgärder inom energieffektivitet (EE)/ förnybara energikällor (RES). Detta avser främst offentliga byggnader.
Förslaget utgör en logisk fortsättning av projektets andra fas som sedan 2014 implementeras av UNDP och som finansieras av Sida. Den andra fasen kommer att avslutas i februari 2021. Det pågående projektet har hittills uppnått många goda resultat och har lyckats öka energieffektiviteten i BiH. Baserat på förväntningarna av projektets föregående implementeringsfas är det tydligt att projektet bör fortsätta och utökas, även om mycket redan har genomförts. Det finns ett stort behov av förbättringar av offentliga byggnader i BiH, dels för att minska energiförbrukningen och för att reducera utsläppen. I linje med projektmålen består projektet av sju sammanhörande och kompletterande komponenter: - Kapacitetsutveckling (PC1) - utveckla kapaciteten och stärka kunskapen inom miljöministeriet (Ministeriet för utrikes handel och esterna relationer, på engelska förkortat MoFTER), miljöfonderna (Envronmental Funds) och fackfolk inom energiområdet. - Institutionalisering och energihantering (PC2) – institutionalisera, d v s bygga in kunskap och system för, hanteringen av energi, kostnader och utsläppen från offentliga byggnader i BiH. - Juridiska ramverk/finansiella mekanismer (PC3) - utveckla och införa hållbara finansiella mekanismer. - Infrastrukturella åtgärder (PC4) - implementera åtgärder för energieffektivisering i offentliga byggnader. - Allmän kännedom/ marknadsföringskampanjer (PC5) - öka det allmänna medvetandet om energieffektivitet. - RES off-grid-lösningar (PC6) - Förse hushåll som befinner sig utanför nätet med energikällor. - RES/EE i små och medelstora företag (SME) (PC7) - öka RES/EE i SME:s runt om i BiH. Projektet ämnar också bidra till ”grön återhämtning” efter COVID. Detta genom att bidra till teknisk och ekonomisk stimulans för minskade utsläpp av växthusgaser (GHG), förbättrad luftkvalitet, nya jobb, budgetbesparingar/återskapande av resurser för ”gröna” investeringar etc. Halvtids- och avslutande utvärdering av nuvarande GED-projekt (GED II) pågår och kommer att avslutas under början av 2021. Slutsatserna och rekommendationerna från utvärderingen kommer därför, inom ramarna för startperioden, att inkluderas i det nya projektet.

The main goal of Green Economic Development phase III project is to further facilitate scaling up of energy efficiency in BIH and the creation of a favourable environment for investing in Energy Efficiency (EE)/Renewable Energy Sources(RES) measures in BiH, primarily in public sector buildings. The intervention presents logical continuation to the 2nd phase of the Green Economic Project implemented by UNDP and financed by Sweden since 2014, which is coming to its end in February 2021. The ongoing project has achieved many good results and managed in scaling up energy efficiency in BIH. Based on the experience from the previous implementation phases of the Project, though a lot has been done, it is evident that the project should further scale up activities implemented under the GED II, as there is a huge need to improve the public building stock in BiH as to reduce consumption and consequently emissions. In accordance with the goal, the Programme consists of seven interlinked and supplementing project components: - Capacity Building (PC1) – Develop capacity and strengthen skills of MoFTER, Env. Funds staff and energy professionals - Institutionalization of energy management (PC2) – Institutionalization of energy, costs and emission management and monitoring in public sector buildings of BiH - Legislative framework / financial mechanisms (PC3) – Development and adoption of sustainable financial mechanisms - Infrastructure measures (PC4) – Implementation of energy efficiency measures in public buildings - Public awareness / marketing campaign (PC5) – increasing public awareness on energy efficiency - RES off-grid solutions (PC6) – Provide access to energy for off grid households in BiH - RES/EE in SME's (PC7) – Increased EE/RES in SME's in BIH The project also aims to contribute to COVID “green recovery” by providing technical and economic stimulus to GHG emission reduction, air quality improvement, creation of new jobs, budgetary savings/ re-generating resources for investment etc. Mid/end term evaluation of the current GED project is ongoing, and will be finalized in early 2021, therefore findings and recommendations from the evaluation report will be incorporated into new project within the inception phase period.

The primarily goal of Green Economic Development 3rd phase project is to contribute to the creation of a favorable environment for investing in EE and RES measures in BiH. Short-term aim of the GED 3rd phase project is to create interest and motivate end-users to invest into EE/RES by promoting co-financing, develop capacity and skills of Environmental Funds (systematic approach to decision making processes of EE/RES investments) and achieve budget cost savings through implementation of EE/RES projects and reinvest savings into EE/RES or other infrastructure projects. Mid-term aim of the GED 3rd phase project is to generate employment of domestic workforce, increase public awareness and understanding of EE/RES benefits, develop and adopt sustainable financial mechanisms for EE project financing (performance based granting, ESCO Fund window), contribute to BiH’s EU accession (EPBD, EED and RES directives) and lower the risk to enter EE investments/provide loans for EE/RES investments in BiH. The project will also contribute to COVID “green recovery” by providing technical and economic stimulus to GHG emission reduction, air quality improvement, creation of new jobs, budgetary savings/ re-generating resources for investment etc.

tag.narrative: 11.6 - By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management.
11.6 - Till 2030 minska städernas negativa miljöpåverkan per person, bland annat genom att ägna särskild uppmärksamhet åt luftkvalitet samt hantering av kommunalt och annat avfall.
7.3 - By 2030, double the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency.
7.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla den globala förbättringstakten vad gäller energieffektivitet.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

title.narrative: Global Fund for Women
Global Fund for Women

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Global Fund for Women (GFW) är en av världens ledande fonder för jämställdhet och kvinnors och flickors mänskliga rättigheter. De använder sitt nätverk för att driva påverkansarbete, samla in pengar, och förmedla medel till kvinnorättsorganisationer. Deras strategi är att finansiera och samarbeta med organisationer ledda av kvinnor, flickor och transpersoner som kämpar för jämställdhet och mänskliga rättigheter i sina egna samhällen.
GFWs verksamhet syftar till att stärka kvinnorörelsen som helhet. Genom att bidra till ökat fokus på jämställdhetsfrågor och kvinnors och flickor rättigheter, ökad finansiering till kvinnorättsorganisationer, förändrade sociala normer och förbättrad lagstiftning bidrar de till resultat inom såväl SRHR, kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt och arbetet mot könsrelaterat våld.
Sidas finansiering kommer att öka GFWs kapacitet att stödja kvinnorättsorganisationer på gräsrotsnivå världen över. I dagsläget bidrar GFW med finansiering till ca 300 organisationer årligen och med Sidas stöd kommer ytterligare 37-56 organisationer per år få finansiellt stöd. Insatsen är särskilt relevant givet den backlash som råder vad gäller kvinnors rättigheter och det krympande utrymmet som finns för organisationer i civilsamhället att agera fritt och oberoende och som begränsar deras tillgång till hållbar finansiering.
Sidas stöd är ett programstöd men som i praktiken kommer att finansiera GFWs verksamhet i sin helhet så som den definieras av deras övergripande strategiska plan och programmatiska strategier. Enligt den nuvarande strategiska planen ska GFWs verksamhet resultera i följande till 2020: - Nå det årliga insamlingsmålet på 25 miljoner USD och vidareförmedla minst 15 miljoner USD till kvinnorättsorganisationer. - Stärkta sociala rörelser som kämpar för kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter och fördjupad expertis inom området. - Utökat inflytande och räckvidd. Säkra och underhålla interaktion/kommunikation med 2 miljoner individer årligen. - Mobilisera och tillgängliggöra minst 110 miljoner USD till kvinnorättsrörelsen genom strategiska allianser. - Uppmuntra flexibilitet, samarbete och innovation i system, kultur och talangutveckling.
Sedan sommaren 2019 har GFW genom en bred inkluderande process arbetat med att ta fram en vision för deras arbete fram till 2030 och en ny strategisk plan för 2020-2023. Sida har informerats om processen och delats bakgrundsanalyserna samt har välkomnats att inkomma med feedback.
GFWs programmatiska strategier fokuserar på SRHR, frihet från våld, ekonomisk rättvisa, kvinnligt ledarskap, jämställdhet och teknologi samt främjandet av andra kvinnofonder. De övergripande programmatiska prioriteringarna förväntas bestå även under kommande strategiperiod.
GFW har 42 anställda med huvudkontor i San Fransisco men med ett antal medarbetare baserade i New York av praktiska och strategiska skäl. Organisationsformen är en icke-vinstdrivande ”benefit corporation” registrerad under kalifornisk lag vilket innebär att de arbetar uteslutande för välgörenhets- och utbildningsändamål och är skattebefriade. GFWs verksamhet styrs av deras stadgar och styrelse som utgörs av experter inom kvinnors rättigheter, internationella normativa ramverk, filantropi och teknologi. Styrelsen är oavlönad. Styrelsen har den yttersta beslutsmakten och är organiserad i stående och ad hoc kommittéer med olika funktionella funktioner/ansvarsområden så som finansiering, revision eller programverksamhet. GFWs verkställande direktör (VD) är en ex-officio medlem i styrelsen men har inte rösträtt. Den dagliga verksamheten leds av GFWs VD med stöd av en ledningsgrupp.
GFW är ny som avtalspartner till Sida men är välkända som aktörer då de är en del av AmplifyChange konsortiet som finansieras av Sida genom strategin för social hållbar utveckling. Eftersom att GFW är en ny partner till Sida har avtalet utformats som ett programstöd för att skapa ramar för att det faktum att Sida inte har full insikt i GFWs kapacitet och kontrollmekanismer och att GFW inte arbetat med bilaterala givare i större utsträckning tidigare. På sikt, efter att ISK-granskning genomförts och om samarbetet fungerar väl bör ett kärnstöd övervägas.
GFWs totala årsbudget (2019) är ca 182 miljoner kronor, varav 127 miljoner (70%) är medel som tillhandahålls av individer, 25 miljoner från filantroper och företag och endast 2 miljoner av bilaterala givare/multilateraler. Minst hälften av GFW's årliga budget samt hälften av Sidas medel kommer att vidarebefordras från GFW till lokala kvinnorättsorganisationer, främst i det globala Syd.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Programme support amounting to in total 100 MSEK will be provided to Global Fund for Women (GFW) for the period 2019-2022.
The purpose of the intervention is to support GFW’s work as described in their current Strategic Plan 2015-2020 and corresponding programmatic strategies. The Strategic Plan sets out the organization’s ambition to achieve the following five goals by 2020: 1) Accelerate fundraising to support increased grantmaking, advocacy, and resource mobilization for women’s human rights: By 2020, reach 25 MUSD annual revenue and distribute a minimum of 15 MUSD in grants. 2) Strengthen Movements to Advance Women’s Human Rights, Deepen Movement-Building Expertise: Demonstrate clear impact on women’s rights and movements via grant making, advocacy, and influencing strategies. 3) Extend Reach and Influence, reaching an aggregated audience of 2 million by 2020: Initiate and change critical conversations on women’s rights and strengthen reputation and influence. 4) Mobilize Resources through High-Impact Strategic Alliances, generating at least 110 MUSD in cash and/or in-kind resources. 5) Embed Nimbleness, Innovation, and Collaboration through systems, culture, talent, activities, and values.
The programmatic focus areas are freedom from violence, economic justice, and sexual and reproductive health and rights. On these themes they campaign and award grants to grass-roots women’s groups. GFW also provide grants to groups using Media and Technology as well as Leadership Development as part of their work, and partner with global Women’s Funds as key resource mobilizers.
Sida’s funding will increase GFW’s ability to respond to the immediate needs of grassroots women’s rights organizations that are facing increased hostility – including violence, erosion of funding, and roll backs to existing rights; and increase GFW’s ability to foster and support the growth of feminist movements that will ensure long-term progress.
GFW's total budget is 182 million SEK (FY2019), out of which 127 million SEK (70%) is provided by individuals, 25 million SEK by philanthropic donors and corporations and only 2 million SEK by bilateral/multilateral donors. At least half of GFW's annual budget and Sida's contribution will go directly to grants to women's rights organizations at grassroot level, almost exclusively in the Global South.

The purpose of the intervention is to support GFW’s work as described by their current Strategic Plan 2020-2023. The plan positions GFW to equip movements with felxible financing and recourses to maximize their impact and drive meaningful change by focusing on the following 6 goals: Movements Lead - GFW have supported gender justice movements to build more grassroots people power to transform systems that perpetuate injustice. Transition Thoughtfully - GFW have successfully transitioned to a movement-focused approach to support gender justice movements based on their needs. Offer Paths to Better Giving - GFW have mobilized more and better resources to support gender justice movements. Speak Up - GFW have leveraged and built influence and visibility to foster the gender justice movement ecosystem. Practice What We Preach - GFW have aligned all elements of our internal operations with our vision and values. Partner with Purpose - GFW have developed strategic partnerships to bring additional resources and capabilities to support gender justice movements. By shifting towards an approach that allows for movements to determine their own needs and allocate resources accordingly, GFW aims to model feminist funding principles long championed by the women’s funds community and meet the most urgent needs in the fight for gender justice to drive transormative change.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer

title.narrative: Avtal mellan Sida och Global Fund for Women
Beslut om insats, Global Fund for Women
Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: Global Fund for Women's (GFW) vision is a world where movements for gender justice have transformed power and privilege for a few into equity and equality for all. They contribute to this goal through their mission of funding boldand expansive gender justice movements who are creating meaningful change that will last beyond our lifetimes. Amidst unprecedented challenges—from the growing global pandemic to rising authoritarian governments to environmental degradation—GFW's model of feminist philanthropy has proven to be an effective way to shift power and resources to communities most impacted by inequality and injustice, and rally behind their solutions. The same principles that guide GFW's work—forging long-term relationships grounded in trust, centering the needs of those who most experience marginalization, seeding underfunded or unregistered groups, and providing flexible, multi-year grants that allow partners to freely direct funding— meant that they were ready to respond quickly when each crisis came. Over the past year, GFW have supported opportunities for learning, solidarity, and joint action across aligned movements, all while responding to the immediate needs of our community. In fiscal year 2020 GFW awarded 9 607 487 USD via 349 grants to grantee partners in 79 countries. There average grant size have ranged from 13 000 USD to 57 000 USD. 84% of these grants were awarded in countries where civil society is closed, repressed, or obstruccted by government. The grantee partners have helped change 14 laws and policies in 12 countries during the last fiscal year, including: - repeal of a proposal for harsher restrictions on abortion in El Salvador - an increase in the national budget for disaster management in Indonesia - passage of a draft decree protecting collective land rights of Souliyate women in Morocco - exemption of taxes on sanitary product in Zimbabwe - ratification of the Domestic Workers Convention No. 189 with the ILO by Mexico, expanding protections for 2,3 million domestic workers of which the majority are women and many of which are in vulnerable situations, indigenous or from rural areas. Coronovirus Response Recognizing the disparate impact on already marginalized communities and the overall challenges of surviving amidst a pandemic under lockdown, GFW’s Crisis Fund has allowed them to provide grantee partners with flexible funding and support, rapidly responding to health risks, technology, and shifts in global priorities. Many of GFW's partners have maintained momentum for political change and accountability by organizing online during the pandemic. As they stepped up their online presence, the Crisis Fund provided support with digital capacity strengthening and ensuring digital security for their communities. Funds were also directed to partners facilitating services that other providers, including overnments, deprioritized—like running help lines for survivors of domestic violence and protecting abortion access during shelter-in-place orders. Across the globe, this flexible funding is supporting women and girl-led organizations to reach communities most impacted, and grounded in their needs. In addition to the crisis grants, GFW has been a leading voice in the philanthropic community advocating for community-led response, flexible funding, increased giving, and gender-sensitive solutions. GFW has also advocated that humanitarian aid strategies must consider both how disasters and recovery efforts themselves impact people differently across gender, race, ethnicity, disability, class, and age. Prioritizing Holistic Care for Movements Across the world, the rise of conservative regimes is creating a backlash against activists’ hardwon progress for gender justice. Those fighting for sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) continue to stand against increasingly regressive policies, all while advocating and caring for their communities. To fuel their movements, GFW strive to equip leaders and organizations with the resources to not only address systemicinequalities, but sustain their spirits for the long haul. The past year, GFW have supported partners as they stood up for SRHR, honoring activists’ wellbeing as a key part of this work. Thanks to flexible funding, local women’s groups and feminist funds have been able to strategize and celebrate collectively, driving forward change while nourishing current and future generations of activists. By prioritizing holistic support for partners along with crisis response, GFW's philosophy of feminist philanthropy recognizes that it takes great strength to provide great care, especially from within communities most impacted by injustices. Reach and influence Last year, GFW launched an award-winning documentary short film series called Fundamental: Gender Justice No Exceptions, featuring grentee partners leadning movements in Brazil, Kenya, Pakistan, Georgia, and the United States. The films has been viewd more than 3,5 million times. Through GFW's communications channels, the amplified voices of grassroots women's rights organizations are reaching 190,8 million people annually.

They contribute to this goal through their mission of funding boldand expansive gender justice movements who are creating meaningful change that will last beyond our lifetimes. Amidst unprecedented challenges—from the growing global pandemic to rising authoritarian governments to environmental degradation—GFW's model of feminist philanthropy has proven to be an effective way to shift power and resources to communities most impacted by inequality and injustice, and rally behind their solutions. The same principles that guide GFW's work—forging long-term relationships grounded in trust, centering the needs of those who most experience marginalization, seeding underfunded or unregistered groups, and providing flexible, multi-year grants that allow partners to freely direct funding— meant that they were ready to respond quickly when each crisis came. Over the past year, GFW have supported opportunities for learning, solidarity, and joint action across aligned movements, all while responding to the immediate needs of our community. In fiscal year 2020 GFW awarded 9 607 487 USD via 349 grants to grantee partners in 79 countries. There average grant size have ranged from 13 000 USD to 57 000 USD. 84% of these grants were awarded in countries where civil society is closed, repressed, or obstruccted by government. The grantee partners have helped change 14 laws and policies in 12 countries during the last fiscal year, including: - repeal of a proposal for harsher restrictions on abortion in El Salvador - an increase in the national budget for disaster management in Indonesia - passage of a draft decree protecting collective land rights of Souliyate women in Morocco - exemption of taxes on sanitary product in Zimbabwe - ratification of the Domestic Workers Convention No. 189 with the ILO by Mexico, expanding protections for 2,3 million domestic workers of which the majority are women and many of which are in vulnerable situations, indigenous or from rural areas. Coronovirus Response Recognizing the disparate impact on already marginalized communities and the overall challenges of surviving amidst a pandemic under lockdown, GFW’s Crisis Fund has allowed them to provide grantee partners with flexible funding and support, rapidly responding to health risks, technology, and shifts in global priorities. Many of GFW's partners have maintained momentum for political change and accountability by organizing online during the pandemic. As they stepped up their online presence, the Crisis Fund provided support with digital capacity strengthening and ensuring digital security for their communities. Funds were also directed to partners facilitating services that other providers, including overnments, deprioritized—like running help lines for survivors of domestic violence and protecting abortion access during shelter-in-place orders. Across the globe, this flexible funding is supporting women and girl-led organizations to reach communities most impacted, and grounded in their needs. In addition to the crisis grants, GFW has been a leading voice in the philanthropic community advocating for community-led response, flexible funding, increased giving, and gender-sensitive solutions. GFW has also advocated that humanitarian aid strategies must consider both how disasters and recovery efforts themselves impact people differently across gender, race, ethnicity, disability, class, and age. Prioritizing Holistic Care for Movements Across the world, the rise of conservative regimes is creating a backlash against activists’ hardwon progress for gender justice. Those fighting for sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) continue to stand against increasingly regressive policies, all while advocating and caring for their communities. To fuel their movements, GFW strive to equip leaders and organizations with the resources to not only address systemicinequalities, but sustain their spirits for the long haul. The past year, GFW have supported partners as they stood up for SRHR, honoring activists’ wellbeing as a key part of this work. Thanks to flexible funding, local women’s groups and feminist funds have been able to strategize and celebrate collectively, driving forward change while nourishing current and future generations of activists. By prioritizing holistic support for partners along with crisis response, GFW's philosophy of feminist philanthropy recognizes that it takes great strength to provide great care, especially from within communities most impacted by injustices. Reach and influence Last year, GFW launched an award-winning documentary short film series called Fundamental: Gender Justice No Exceptions, featuring grentee partners leadning movements in Brazil, Kenya, Pakistan, Georgia, and the United States. The films has been viewd more than 3,5 million times. Through GFW's communications channels, the amplified voices of grassroots women's rights organizations are reaching 190,8 million people annually.

title.narrative: UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women
UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women

description.narrative: Mission The UNTFs mission is to advocate for, and finance, innovative approaches for preventing and ending violence against women and girls, to catalyse learning from global evidence collected from the projects it funds and to leverage its unique mandate and convening power to foster global giving for EVAW/G. The overall objective; Women and Girls live a life free from Violence Expected outcomes1. Improved access for women and girls to essential, safe and adequate multi-sectoral services to end VAW/G2. Increased effectiveness of legislation, policies, national action plans and accountabilitysystems to prevent and end VAW/G 3. Improved prevention of VAW/G through changes in behaviours, practices and attitudes

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FN: s fond för att eliminera våld mot kvinnor (UNTF) är den enda globala, multilaterala mekanismen som är specialiserad på finansiering och kapacitetsuppbyggnad för att förebygga våld mot kvinnor och flickor, förbättra kvinnors tillgång till adekvata sektorsövergripande tjänster för överlevare samt påverkansarbete för att förespråka effektivt genomförande av lagar och policys runt frågan. UNTF inrättades genom resolution 50/16 i FN:s generalförsamling 1996, som en gemensam fond för FN-systemen, men administrerad av UN Women, för att påskynda arbetet för att förebygga och eliminera våld mot kvinnor och flickor.
Verksamheten syftar till att; - öka våldsutsatta kvinnors tillgång till stöd och service, - stärka framtagande och genomförande av lagar och policys för att förebygga våld mot kvinnor och flickor - stärka förebyggande av våld mot kvinnor och flickor genom insatser för att förändra sociala normer
UNTF arbetar genom tre pelare; finansiering av insatser, som kunskapshub/ evidensnav och för att öka global finansiering för insatser mot våld mot kvinnor och flickor.
1) Finansiering av insatser: UNTF ger finansiering för innovativa och katalytiska fleråriga program som sätter överlevande i centrum för sina interventioner. Programmen genomförs i huvudsak av civilsamhällesorganisationer, men regeringarna kan också ansöka om finansiering. UNTF gör årliga ansökningsomgångar och får 1000 till 2000 ansökningar per år (1300 i 2019) till ett värde av 400-600 MUSD. En omfattande bedömningsprocess äger rum i samband med varje ansökningsomgång och UNTF fördelar 10-15 MUSD till 25-35 nya partners per år. De flesta bidrag är för 3 år, så vid varje given tidpunkt finns det cirka 120 pågående insatser.
2) Kunskapshub: Kunskapshuben/evidensnavet är inrättat för att vara en plattform för att hämta hem, analysera och sprida lärdomar från verksamheten i de projekt UNTF finansierar och för att informera politik och policyarbete inom området. De organisationer som erhåller finansiering representerar en global dynamisk och mycket kunnig grupp av aktörer. Effekterna av deras arbete visar att våld mot kvinnor och flickor kan minskas, förhindras och slutligen elimineras.
3) Resursmobilisering: pelaren är ett direkt svar på den kroniska underfinansieringen av insatser för att förebygga och eliminera våld mot kvinnor och flickor. Aktiviteterna är global resursmobiliseing, kampanjer och opinionsbildning. Mycket fokus ligger på att beskriva organisationernas verksamhet som ett sätt att stärka argumentationen för vikten av finansiering av arbete för att förebygga och hindra våld mot kvinnor och flickor.
Kärnstöd om 30 MSEK per år i 3 år (totalt 90 MSEK) planeras till UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women (UNTF) för perioden 2019-2022. Insatsens totala budget är ca 450 MSEK för avtalsperioden.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Core support amounting to 30 MSEK per year for 3 years (in total SEK 90 million) will be provided to UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women (UNTF) for the period 2019-2022.
The activities are aimed at; -Increasing access to support and service for women with violence; -Strengthening the development and implementation of laws and policies to prevent violence against women and girls -Strengthening the prevention of violence against women and girls through efforts to change social norms
The UNTF works through three pillars; 1) Funding of interventions, 2) as a knowledge hub/evidence platform and 3) to increase global funding for action against violence against women and girls. Funding of operations is implemented through calls for NGOs and other players to apply for funding.

participating-org.narrative: UNWOMEN/United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women
United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

title.narrative: Agreement between Sida and UN Women, UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women
Amendment No. 1 to the Agreement between Sida and UN Women, UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women
Beslut om insats, UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence Against Women
Beslut om ändring av insats, UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence Against Women
Ingen resultattitel tillgänglig
Objectives

description.narrative: Results in 2019 The UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women have achieved substantive results in 2019. The number of persons reached by the projects funded by the UNTF is impressive and Sida assess that the work of the grantees do make a real difference for Women and Girls that are victims of Violence in many countries and both in the short and in the long run. The combination of immediate support to report violence or get access to legal aid in combination with continuous efforts to engage community and faith leaders, support to schools to improve their curricula and to building women's rights organizations capacity to mobilize additional resources is assessed to be relevant and effective. The projects funded by the UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women have managed to reach large numbers of refugee and internally displaced women and girls and women and girls living with disabilities. The intervention is therefore assessed to have a strong poverty perspective and to contribute to the objective of "leaving no one behind". UNTFs narrative and financial report for 2019 has been received and approved in accordance to the agreement in June 2020. Amendment 2020 UNTF has during spring 2020 been very quick in adjusting and expanding their grant giving to enable that Women's Rights organisations all over the world can respond to the new challenges the pandemic has led to. These challenges encompass both increased levels of violence against women and girls and also decreased capacity from regular protection mechanism to prevent violence and support victims of violence. In addition the pandemic is also posing additional pressure on small WROs that are often dependant on project funding and that are are now at risk of having to discontinue activities. Therefore UNTF are moving as much as possible from program funding to core support to contribute to the preconditions for small WROs (and thereby the women's movement)to sustain during the pandemic. UNTF is by Sida assessed to have the systems and networks in place to expand their programs. An amendment of the agreement with UN Women for funding to UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women and Girls (UNTF) was made in July 2020.The amendment entail additional funding amounting to 7 MSEK to UNTF tosupport their Covid-19 response. New strategic Plan 2021-2025 UNTF is carrying out a comprehensive process during 2020 to formulate their new strategic plan. Sida has contributed actively both in interviews with consultants and i donor meetings. Sidas key messages has been that; -the UNTF shall keep focus on WROs and especially small WROs -that core support and capacity buildning are important mechanisms for sustainable results. -that the UNTF need to formulate how it will work to influence national governments to increase their engagement and committments to eliminate VoW.

In addition the pandemic is also posing additional pressure on small WROs that are often dependant on project funding and that are are now at risk of having to discontinue activities. Therefore UNTF are moving as much as possible from program funding to core support to contribute to the preconditions for small WROs (and thereby the women's movement)to sustain during the pandemic. UNTF is by Sida assessed to have the systems and networks in place to expand their programs. An amendment of the agreement with UN Women for funding to UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women and Girls (UNTF) was made in July 2020.The amendment entail additional funding amounting to 7 MSEK to UNTF tosupport their Covid-19 response. New strategic Plan 2021-2025 UNTF is carrying out a comprehensive process during 2020 to formulate their new strategic plan. Sida has contributed actively both in interviews with consultants and i donor meetings. Sidas key messages has been that; -the UNTF shall keep focus on WROs and especially small WROs -that core support and capacity buildning are important mechanisms for sustainable results. -that the UNTF need to formulate how it will work to influence national governments to increase their engagement and committments to eliminate VoW.

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women
COVID-19 UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women

description.narrative: Mission The UNTFs mission is to advocate for, and finance, innovative approaches for preventing and ending violence against women and girls, to catalyse learning from global evidence collected from the projects it funds and to leverage its unique mandate and convening power to foster global giving for EVAW/G. The overall objective; Women and Girls live a life free from Violence Expected outcomes1. Improved access for women and girls to essential, safe and adequate multi-sectoral services to end VAW/G2. Increased effectiveness of legislation, policies, national action plans and accountabilitysystems to prevent and end VAW/G 3. Improved prevention of VAW/G through changes in behaviours, practices and attitudes

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Core support amounting to 30 MSEK per year for 3 years (in total SEK 90 million) will be provided to UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women (UNTF) for the period 2019-2022.
The activities are aimed at; -Increasing access to support and service for women with violence; -Strengthening the development and implementation of laws and policies to prevent violence against women and girls -Strengthening the prevention of violence against women and girls through efforts to change social norms
The UNTF works through three pillars; 1) Funding of interventions, 2) as a knowledge hub/evidence platform and 3) to increase global funding for action against violence against women and girls. Funding of operations is implemented through calls for NGOs and other players to apply for funding.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FN: s fond för att eliminera våld mot kvinnor (UNTF) är den enda globala, multilaterala mekanismen som är specialiserad på finansiering och kapacitetsuppbyggnad för att förebygga våld mot kvinnor och flickor, förbättra kvinnors tillgång till adekvata sektorsövergripande tjänster för överlevare samt påverkansarbete för att förespråka effektivt genomförande av lagar och policys runt frågan. UNTF inrättades genom resolution 50/16 i FN:s generalförsamling 1996, som en gemensam fond för FN-systemen, men administrerad av UN Women, för att påskynda arbetet för att förebygga och eliminera våld mot kvinnor och flickor.
Verksamheten syftar till att; - öka våldsutsatta kvinnors tillgång till stöd och service, - stärka framtagande och genomförande av lagar och policys för att förebygga våld mot kvinnor och flickor - stärka förebyggande av våld mot kvinnor och flickor genom insatser för att förändra sociala normer
UNTF arbetar genom tre pelare; finansiering av insatser, som kunskapshub/ evidensnav och för att öka global finansiering för insatser mot våld mot kvinnor och flickor.
1) Finansiering av insatser: UNTF ger finansiering för innovativa och katalytiska fleråriga program som sätter överlevande i centrum för sina interventioner. Programmen genomförs i huvudsak av civilsamhällesorganisationer, men regeringarna kan också ansöka om finansiering. UNTF gör årliga ansökningsomgångar och får 1000 till 2000 ansökningar per år (1300 i 2019) till ett värde av 400-600 MUSD. En omfattande bedömningsprocess äger rum i samband med varje ansökningsomgång och UNTF fördelar 10-15 MUSD till 25-35 nya partners per år. De flesta bidrag är för 3 år, så vid varje given tidpunkt finns det cirka 120 pågående insatser.
2) Kunskapshub: Kunskapshuben/evidensnavet är inrättat för att vara en plattform för att hämta hem, analysera och sprida lärdomar från verksamheten i de projekt UNTF finansierar och för att informera politik och policyarbete inom området. De organisationer som erhåller finansiering representerar en global dynamisk och mycket kunnig grupp av aktörer. Effekterna av deras arbete visar att våld mot kvinnor och flickor kan minskas, förhindras och slutligen elimineras.
3) Resursmobilisering: pelaren är ett direkt svar på den kroniska underfinansieringen av insatser för att förebygga och eliminera våld mot kvinnor och flickor. Aktiviteterna är global resursmobiliseing, kampanjer och opinionsbildning. Mycket fokus ligger på att beskriva organisationernas verksamhet som ett sätt att stärka argumentationen för vikten av finansiering av arbete för att förebygga och hindra våld mot kvinnor och flickor.
Kärnstöd om 30 MSEK per år i 3 år (totalt 90 MSEK) planeras till UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women (UNTF) för perioden 2019-2022. Insatsens totala budget är ca 450 MSEK för avtalsperioden.

Objectives

description.narrative: Results in 2019 The UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women have achieved substantive results in 2019. The number of persons reached by the projects funded by the UNTF is impressive and Sida assess that the work of the grantees do make a real difference for Women and Girls that are victims of Violence in many countries and both in the short and in the long run. The combination of immediate support to report violence or get access to legal aid in combination with continuous efforts to engage community and faith leaders, support to schools to improve their curricula and to building women's rights organizations capacity to mobilize additional resources is assessed to be relevant and effective. The projects funded by the UNTF to Eliminate Violence against Women have managed to reach large numbers of refugee and internally displaced women and girls and women and girls living with disabilities. The intervention is therefore assessed to have a strong poverty perspective and to contribute to the objective of "leaving no one behind". UNTFs narrative and financial report for 2019 has been received and approved in accordance to the agreement in June 2020. Amendment 2020 UNTF has during spring 2020 been very quick in adjusting and expanding their grant giving to enable that Women's Rights organisations all over the world can respond to the new challenges the pandemic has led to. These challenges encompass both increased levels of violence against women and girls and also decreased capacity from regular protection mechanism to prevent violence and support victims of violence. In addition the pandemic is also posing additional pressure on small WROs that are often dependant on project funding and that are are now at risk of having to discontinue activities. Therefore UNTF are moving as much as possible from program funding to core support to contribute to the preconditions for small WROs (and thereby the women's movement)to sustain during the pandemic. UNTF is by Sida assessed to have the systems and networks in place to expand their programs. An amendment of the agreement with UN Women for funding to UN Trust Fund to Eliminate Violence against Women and Girls (UNTF) was made in July 2020.The amendment entail additional funding amounting to 7 MSEK to UNTF tosupport their Covid-19 response. New strategic Plan 2021-2025 UNTF is carrying out a comprehensive process during 2020 to formulate their new strategic plan. Sida has contributed actively both in interviews with consultants and i donor meetings. Sidas key messages has been that; -the UNTF shall keep focus on WROs and especially small WROs -that core support and capacity buildning are important mechanisms for sustainable results. -that the UNTF need to formulate how it will work to influence national governments to increase their engagement and committments to eliminate VoW.
